[[File:Parc natural de l'alt pirineu.jpg|250px]] | photo_alt = | photo_caption = | photo_width = | map = Spain Catalonia | map_alt = | map_caption = Location of the natural park in [[Catalonia]] | map_width = | location = [[Province of Lleida]], [[Catalonia]], [[Spain]] | nearest_city = | coordinates = {{coords|42|29|46|N|1|12|38|E|region:ES-CT|display=inline, title}} | area = {{convert|69850|ha}} | established = {{Start date|2003}} | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = [[Generalitat de Catalunya]] | world_heritage_site = | url = http://www.gencat.cat/parcs/alt_pirineu }} '''Alt Pirineu Natural Park''' ({{lang-ca|Parc Natural de l'Alt Pirineu}}) is the largest [[natural park (Spain)|natural park]] in [[Catalonia]], [[Spain]]. The park was established in 2003 by the [[Generalitat of Catalonia|Generalitat de Catalunya]] and covers an area of {{convert|69850|ha}}, including the highest peaks of the [[Pyrenees]] in Catalonia. It stretches over the [[Comarques of Catalonia|comarques]] of [[Pallars SobirÃ ]] and [[Alt Urgell]].{{cite web |url=http://www.lleidatur.com/tourism/visit/upper-pyrenees-natural-park/168.aspx |title= Alt Pirineu Natural Park |author= |date= |work=DiputaciÃ³ de Lleida - ARA LLEIDA |publisher=lleidatur.com |accessdate=February 5, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://territori.scot.cat/cat/notices/parc_natural_de_l_alt_pirineu_2004_629.php |title= PARC NATURAL DE L'ALT PIRINEU |author=Marta PallarÃ¨s |date=December 31, 2004 |work=Observatori de projectes i debats territorials de Catalunya |publisher=scot.cat |accessdate=February 5, 2012|language=ca}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.gencat.cat/parcs/alt_pirineu}} {{ca icon}} {{es icon}} {{Protected areas of Catalonia}} [[Category:Alt Urgell]] [[Category:Natural parks of Catalonia]] [[Category:Pallars SobirÃ ]] [[Category:Province of Lleida]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 2003]] [[Category:Pyrenees]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Spain]] {{Lleida-geo-stub}} {{Protected-area-stub}}

The indicator is an "annual prevalence" rate which is the percentage of the youth and adult population who have consumed cannabis at least once in the past survey year. ==Table== The primary source of information is the ''World Drug Report 2011'' (WDR 2011),[http://www.unodc.org/unodc/en/data-and-analysis/WDR-2011.html World Drug Report 2011]. {{EngvarB|date=June 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} '''Arc Manche''' (French: ''arc'', "arch"; and ''[[English Channel|La Manche]]'', "the English Channel") is a co-operation network aiming to gather territories bordering the Channel in France and in Great Britain, to advocate the shared interests of this area and to promote Franco-British co-operation. It enables local stakeholders to share [[best practices]] and to consult each other when they face common issues, especially in the [[sea|maritime]] area. This network is also a means to support large scale bi-national projects that may benefit from [[Structural Funds and Cohesion Funds|European funds]], such as CAMIS.
The Channel Arc Assembly is currently chaired by the [[Haute-Normandie]] region.
== General data<ref>source : ''Cross Channel'' atlas and ''Channel Spaces : A World within Europe'', P. BulÃ©on and L. Shurmer-Smith, 2007. Regarding the data, addition of the relevant statistics from counties of Cornwall, Devon, Dorset, Hampshire, West Sussex, East Sussexd, Kent, and from regions of Brittany, Lower Normandy, Upper Normandy, Picardie and Nord-Pas-de-Calais, 2002 [https://oit.emdi.certic.unicaen.fr/atlas-emdi/ Outil dâintelligence territoriale EMDI] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303202100/https://oit.emdi.certic.unicaen.fr/atlas-emdi/ |date=3 March 2016 }}</ref>==
===Geography===
The [[English Channel]] is one of the world's busiest [[shipping lane]]s, primarily because of its strategic location as the entry/exit door to the [[European Union]]. It links the Atlantic Ocean with the [[North Sea]], which generates considerable flows in people and goods, and makes it one of the main exchange zones in Europe.
It engenders a concentration of maritime opportunities, but also risks, which explains the co-operation between French and British local authorities in areas like maritime security, [[marine pollution]] prevention or the preservation of [[biodiversity]].
This area is 112,519 sqm. Large, including the 530 [[Channel Islands|islands]] it encompasses.
===Demographics===
The area's total population was 17,503,211 inhabitants in 2002, of which 5,445,000 resided in the United Kingdom and 12,058,211 in France.
===Economy===
Total GDP (1998â2000) : 364,829 million Euros
[[GDP per capita]] (1998â2000) : 20,395 Euros
The economic structure of the area is heterogeneous. The North of France is a highly industrialised area, whereas the rich [[South East England|South East of England]] mostly relies on [[high tech]] services and the tourism sector. In France and Great Britain, the most western part of the area has a more rural economy relying on agriculture and tourism: [[Brittany]], [[Lower Normandy]], Cornwall. Fishing is also, in some parts of the area, an important activity. There are 18 maritime quarters and 50 important fishing ports in the area.
Tourism is a structuring activity for the area : in 2004, about 84 million tourists have travelled within the Channel area. 32 sites are listed as [[UNESCO World Heritage site]]s, like the [[Jurassic Coast]], the [[Mont Saint-Michel]], [[Stonehenge]] or the city of [[Le Havre]].
==The Channel Arc Manche partnership==
===Aims===
The promotion of the Channel Arc Manche co-operation network originates from two main concerns :
# To develop the recognition of the Channel Arc among political and institutional stakeholders, may they be private, local, national or European.
It entails interventions at the national and European levels, the reinforcement of a common strategic vision to be able to have influence on the European regional policy, and for the specificities of this maritime space to be taken into account.
# Promote and intensify Franco-British Cooperation
By constituting a stakeholders' network on coastal and maritime issues, by encouraging co-operation in areas of common interest, by supporting exchanges in economic, social, cultural and administrative realms.
===Timeline===
'''2001â2002''' : consultation of local executives concerning the revival of the Channel Arc Manche.
'''20 March 2003''' : Common declaration, signed by the 5 French Regions bordering the Channel and 5 Southern England local authorities.
'''2005''' : Creation of the Channel Arc Manche Assembly : [[Alain Le Vern]], President of the Haute-Normandie Region, is elected chairman and Brad Watson becomes vice-chairman.
'''2004''' : [http://www.emdi.certic.unicaen.fr/en/news.html Espace Manche Development Initiative] project, which was elaborated within the framework of the [[Interreg]] European programme.
'''2006''' â Following the lobbying efforts of the Channel Arc Manche Assembly towards the European Union, the French and British territories bordering the Channel become fully eligible to the [[cross-border cooperation]] programmes. First Conference of the Channel Arc Manche Assembly in Fontwell Park (West Sussex). Presentation of the Channel area strategic vision, elaborated within the framework of the EMDI project.
'''2007''' â creation of the Channel's federation of regional and local ports in [[Saint-Brieuc]]. Brad Watson becomes president of the Channel Arc Manche Assembly.
'''2008''' : (June) publication of the book ''"Channel Spaces, a world within Europe"'', edited by Pascal BulÃ©on and Louis Shurmer-Smith. (December) â Conference of the Channel Arc Manche Assembly in [[Folkestone]], about coastal zones' adjustment to [[climate change]].
2009 : (June) Approval of the CAMIS (Channel Arc Manche Integrated Strategy) project, co-financed by the [http://www.interreg4a-manche.eu/ Interreg IVA France (Channel) â England] programme. In December, Channel Arc Manche Conference in [[Rouen]] : Â« What are the challenges for coastal economies in the Channel? Trends, current situations and local experience in coastal towns. Â»
2011 : Annual conference of the Channel Arc Manhe in [[FÃ©camp]] : "Tackling maritime pollution risks in the Channel for local authorities" parallel to the CAMIS project. Adpoption of the FÃ©camp Declaration.
====Membership====
Full members are the French Regions and the English local authorities bordering the Channel. Associate members are all other organisations located on this territory and willing to contribute to the achievement of the Channel Arc Manche Assembly's objectives.
''''Full members'''' :
Regions : [[Nord-Pas-de-Calais]], [[Picardy (region)|Picardy]], [[Upper Normandy]], [[Lower Normandy]], Brittany.
County Councils : [[Kent County Council|Kent]], [[West Sussex County Council|West Sussex]], [[Hampshire County Council|Hampshire]], [[Devon County Council|Devon]], [[Brighton and Hove City Council|Brighton and Hove]], [[Southampton City Council|Southampton]].
Associate members : [[East Sussex County Council|East Sussex]] and the [[Isle of Wight County Council|Isle of Wight]].
====Bureau====
The Bureau consists of the chairman and the Vice-Chairman of the Assembly. It is respectively [[Alain Le Vern]], is President of the [[Haute-Normandie]] Region. They are elected by full members for two years, and there is an alternation between the French and the British Presidency.
Assisted by the vice-chairman, the chairman must represent and advocate the objectives of the Channel Arc Assembly towards European and national institutions, elaborate common declarations, and make sure the decisions of the Assembly are implemented.
====The Channel Arc Manche Conference====
It gathers full and associate members and the other organisations interested in the Channel Arc Manche. Its yearly meeting takes place during the first week of July, and all members can exchange good practices and identify potential co-operation areas.
====The executive committee==== It consists of all the full members and takes the decisions necessary to the achievements of the Channel Arc Manche Assembly's objectives. It gathers at least twice a year and decisions are taken through consensus.
====Secretariat====
It deals with day-to-day running, the preparation and the follow up of the executive committee's and the annual Conference's work, as well as the website.
====Finances====
The Channel Arc Manche does not have a budget in itself. The means dedicated by its members to the co-operation network mostly consist of working time and limited logistic expenses. European [[structural funds]] are often requested to finance co-operation projects within the Channel area.
==Projects==
European funding, in particular the [[European Regional Development Fund]], enables the [[Interreg]] co-operation programmes to support Franco-British co-operation projects of different scales. 173 million Euros have been allocated to Franco-British co-operation in the Channel between 2007 and 2013. Along with all other projects, the Channel Arc Manche partnership supports more particularly large and structuring projects for the area such as EMDI or CAMIS.
===Espace Manche Development Initiative===
The [http://www.emdi.certic.unicaen.fr/intro.html EMDI] project, which gathered 22 partners between 2004 and 2008, aimed to develop and reinforce Franco-British co-operation within the Channel area. 48% of its budget was co-funded by the Interreg IIIB co-operation programme. It led to :
* The elaboration of a [http://www.emdi.certic.unicaen.fr/documents/strategic_vision/EMDI_DocF_BaT.pdf strategic vision document] for the Channel area. * The development of pilot co-operation actions : tourism, fishing, fisheries, coastal zones integrated management, maritime security, [[intermodal passenger transport|intermodal transport]], [[higher education]], [[research and development]], [[technology transfers]]. * The publication of the bilingual book [http://www.emdi.certic.unicaen.fr/documents/resume_livre.fr.pdf ''Channel Spaces, a World Within Europe''] in 2007. * The maps of the Channel area strategic vision * The [http://atlas-transmanche.certic.unicaen.fr/commun/lecteur2f/racine.php?base=atlas&idlangue=fr Crosschannel Atlas], a Franco-British research collaboration about the Channel area. * The recognition by [[EU institutions]] of the Channel area as a fully pertinent area for [[cross-border cooperation]].
===Channel Arc Manche Integrated Strategy===
The CAMIS project (2009â2013), with a 3.3 million euros budget, half of which is funded by the Interreg IVA France (Channel) England programme, gathers 10 local authorities from Britain and France and 9 organisations.
Aims :
* Promote the specificity of the Channel area in the local, national and European spheres * Improve the knowledge of this area in various realms (geography, economy, biology, etc.) * Develop intermodal transport * Develop innovation, [[workforce development]], economic growth * Create common tools to facilitate and improve the management of certain aspects of the maritime zone such as the Cross channel Forum or the Common resources center. * Ultimately, develop and implement an integrated maritime strategy in the Channel area.
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070929062642/http://www.arcmanche.com/pages_arc/rub_1_e.php3?Page=p_1_2.htm Founding aims of Arc Manche] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060513042536/http://www.arcmanche.com/pages_arc/rub_3_e.php3?Page=p_3_1_1.php3&commun=1&iActID=73 The Arc Manche becomes the Arc Manche Assembly], 12 October 2005 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071008215608/http://www.southeast-ra.gov.uk/our_work/advocacy/europe/strategy/Annex002.pdf South East Regional Assembly â European Strategy for South East England 2001â06], published 2001 *[http://www.southwestuk.eu/files-manager/maritime-conference/460arc_manche_en.pdf Position of the Channel Arc Manche Assembly on the Green Paper "Towards a Maritime Policy for the Union: A European Vision of the Oceans and Seas"]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, 29 June 2007 *[http://www.emdi.certic.unicaen.fr/intro.html EMDI website]

[[File:Aarhusbugten.jpg|right|thumb|Bay of Aarhus viewed from [[Riis Skov]] with the sea bath of ''[[Den Permanente]]'']]
The '''Bay of Aarhus''' or the '''Aarhus Bay''' is a [[Denmark|Danish]] [[waterway]] by [[Aarhus]] in eastern [[Jutland]].
The Bay of Aarhus is bounded by KalÃ¸ Vig in the north, Sletterhage and [[HelgenÃ¦s]] in the east, [[SamsÃ¸]] and [[TunÃ¸]] to the south and the east Jutland coast to the west. The bay stretches over an area of {{convert|610|km2}} and consists of a flat bassin, increasing in depth from 14 m in the west to 18 m in the east. The bay mainly exchanges water with the [[Kattegat]] through a deep trench along HelgenÃ¦s with depths to 50 m. In the bay's southern section there are a number of stony [[reef]]s including Norsminde Flak, Wulffs Flak, Mejlflak and TunÃ¸ Knob. These reefs and the islands of TunÃ¸ and SamsÃ¸, prevents an open connection with the [[Belt Sea]].<ref>[http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Danmarks_geografi_og_historie/Danmarks_geografi/Indre_danske_farvande/%C3%85rhus_Bugt Aarhus Bugt, Den Store Danske]; Aarhus Bugt</ref>
== Environmental issues == In 2002, the inner Danish waters suffered serious and prolonged [[Hypoxia (environmental)|hypoxia]] with the Bay of Aarhus being hit especially hard. Studies by the [[National Environmental Research Institute of Denmark]] (DMU) in November 2002 and March 2003 showed large areas with noticeable damage to [[marine life]], especially around the areas of [[KalÃ¸ Vig]] and the western sections of the bay.<ref>[http://www2.dmu.dk/1_viden/2_Publikationer/3_fagrapporter/rapporter/FR456.PDF OpgÃ¸relse af skadevirkninger pÃ¥ bundfaunaen efter iltsvindet i 2002 i de indre danske farvande]; Rapport nr. 456; 2003; DMU (MiljÃ¸ministeriet)</ref>
In 2013, planning for an offshore [[windmill]] park in the bay on the shallow reef of Mejlflak between TunÃ¸, SamsÃ¸ and HelgenÃ¦s was initiated, scheduled to be completed in 2017.<ref>[http://ing.dk/artikel/siemens-skal-bygge-ultrabillige-havvindmoeller-i-aarhusbugten-171189 Siemens skal bygge ultrabillige havvindmÃ¸ller i Aarhusbugten]; IngeniÃ¸ren.dk, 30 September 2014</ref> In September 2015, the project was put on hold indefinitely as it was not found profitable for energy company [[NRGi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://stiften.dk/aarhus/Omdiskuteret-vindmoellepark-paa-Mejlflak-skrottes/artikel/271427|title=Omdiskuteret vindmÃ¸llepark pÃ¥ Mejlflak skrottes|publisher=Ã rhus Stiftstidende|author=Mortne Ravn|date=28 September 2017|language=Danish|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref>
== Gallery == <gallery> File:Egens Vig, lavvande, sandorm.JPG|The Bay of Aarhus has several shallow coves (Egens Vig at [[KalÃ¸ Castle]]). File:Egens Vig, tiliset.JPG|The Bay of Aarhus rarely freezes up in winter, but some of the shallow coves do occasionally (Egens Vig). File:Bundgarn2.jpg|Sustainable fishing. Commercial fishing in the bay has almost vanished, due in part to ecological collapse. File:Ã rhus bugten.JPG|Around the city of Aarhus, the coast has been secured from erosion. File:Maersk-containerskib.jpg|The port of Aarhus has heavy traffic. File:Dk og isbjerget.png|The bay is very popular for watersports. File:Aarhus LystbÃ¥dehavn 2.JPG|The bay has several [[marina]]s, with two in the [[port of Aarhus]] alone (''Aarhus LystbÃ¥dehavn''). File:RisskovStrand.jpg|Sandy beaches form most of the coastline of the bay. </gallery>

A '''bourne''' is an intermittent [[stream]], flowing from a spring. Frequent in chalk and limestone country where the rock becomes saturated with winter rain, that slowly drains away until the rock becomes dry, when the stream ceases.<ref>{{EB1911|wstitle=Bourne (stream)|display=Bourne|inline=1|volume=4|pages=332-333}}</ref> The word is from the [[Old English language|Anglo-Saxon]] language of England.
The word can be found in northern England in placenames such as: [[Redbourne]], [[Legbourne, Lincolnshire|Legbourne]], but is commonly in used in southern [[England]] (particularly [[Dorset]]) as a name for a small river, particularly in compound names such as [[winterbourne (stream)|winterbourne]]. A winterbourne is a stream or river that is dry through the summer months.
Bourne is used as a place name or as a part of a place name, usually in [[chalk]] [[downland]] countryside. Alternative forms are '''bourn''' or '''borne''' or '''born'''. The apparent variant, '''borne''' found in the placename: [[Camborne]], arises from the [[Cornish language]] and is in fact a [[false friend]]: it refers to a hill (Cornish: ''bronn'', from Common Brythonic ''*brunda''; compare Irish ''bruinn''). '''Born/borne''' in German also means fount, or spring, and is related to the Indo-European root, '''*bhreu'''. That '''born/borne''' appears throughout Europe as a placename is also an important clue that this spelling is an etymological precursor to the Middle English '''bourne/burn'''.
Cf. [[Burn (landform)]], in common use in Scotland and North East England especially, but also found (in placenames) elsewhere in England such as: [[Blackburn]], [[Gisburn]], [[Woburn (disambiguation)|Woburn]], [[Kilburn (disambiguation)|Kilburn]], [[Tyburn]], [[Winkburn]], and so forth.
For rivers and places named Bourne or having this word as part of the name, see [[Bourne (disambiguation)]].

'''COSMO-SkyMed''' ('''CO'''nstellation of small '''S'''atellites for the '''M'''editerranean basin '''O'''bservation) is an [[Earth observation satellite]] [[space-based radar]] system funded by the [[Ministry of Education, Universities and Research (Italy)|Italian Ministry of Research]] and [[Ministry of Defence (Italy)|Ministry of Defence]] and conducted by the [[Italian Space Agency]] (ASI), intended for both military and civilian use.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://earth.esa.int/workshops/polinsar2003/participants/rum74/skymed.pdf | title = COSMO-SkyMed: Mission definition and main applications and products | publisher = [[ESA]]}}</ref>
The space segment of the system includes four identical medium-sized satellites equipped with [[synthetic aperture radar]] (SAR) sensors with global coverage of the planet.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.telespazio.it/cosmo.html |title=COSMO-SkyMed |publisher=[[Telespazio]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070708182009/http://www.telespazio.it/cosmo.html |archivedate=2007-07-08 |df= }}</ref> Observations of an area of interest can be repeated several times a day in all-weather conditions. The imagery will be applied to defense and security assurance in [[Italy]] and other countries, seismic hazard analysis, environmental disaster monitoring, and agricultural mapping.<ref name=SH> {{cite web | url = http://www.spacehab.com/news/2007/07_06_07.htm | title = SPACEHAB Subsidiary Signs New Contracts Totaling $4.7 Million | publisher = [[SPACEHAB]]}}</ref>
== Space segment == The four [[satellite]]s are in [[sun-synchronous]] [[polar orbit]]s with a 97.9Â° inclination at a nominal altitude of 619 km and an orbital period of 97.2 minutes. The local time ascending node at the equator is 06:00. The expected operating life of each satellite is estimated to be 5 years. Each satellite repeats the same [[ground track]] every 16 days, and all of the satellites follow the same ground track. They cross the equator at 06:00 and 18:00 local-time each day. The satellites are phased in the same orbital plane, with COSMO-SkyMed's 1, 2 and 4 at 90Â° to each other and COSMO-SkyMed 3 at 67.5Â° from COSMO-SkyMed 2. This results in varied intervals between the satellites along the same ground track of between 1 and 15 days. The sun-synchronous orbit is used to keep the solar cells illuminated at all times.
The satellites' main components are: *Two [[Photovoltaic module|solar arrays]] for 3.8 [[kilowatt|kW]] at 42 [[volt|V]] [[direct current|DC]] *Stabilization, navigation and [[GPS]] systems *Synthetic aperture radar working in [[X band]] *300 [[Gbit]] on-board [[computer storage|memory]] and 310 [[Mbit/s]] [[data-link]] with [[ground segment]]s
The radar antenna is a phased array that is 1.4 m wide x 5.7 m long. The system is capable of both single- and dual-polarization collection. The center frequency is 9.6 GHz with a maximum radar bandwidth of 400 MHz.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.e-geos.it/products/pdf/csk-user_guide.pdf | title = COSMO-SkyMed User Guide | publisher = ASI}}</ref>
=== Launch === [[United Launch Alliance]] is providing launch services for the first three satellites. Satellite processing for the first two satellites was handled by the Astrotech Space Operations subsidiary of [[SPACEHAB]].<ref name=SH /> The first satellite was launched at 22:34 [[GMT]], on 8 June 2007, aboard a [[Delta II]] 7420-10 rocket from [[Vandenberg AFB]].<ref name="SFN"> {{cite web |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/tracking/index.html |title=Worldwide launch schedule |publisher=Spaceflight Now |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130911172414/http://spaceflightnow.com/tracking/index.html |archivedate=2013-09-11 |df= }}</ref> An identical rocket launched COSMO-2 at 02:31:42 [[GMT]] on 9 December 2007,<ref name=NSF-PL2>[http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/content/?cid=5301 NASA Spaceflight.com â Delta II launches with COSMO-SkyMed-2] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071208094612/http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/content/?cid=5301 |date=December 8, 2007 }}</ref> the launch having been delayed from 6 December due to bad weather, and problems with the rocket's cork insulation. COSMO-3 launched at 02:38 [[GMT]] on 25 October 2008, also aboard a [[Delta II]] 7420-10. A Delta II flying in the 7420-10 configuration will also be used to launch COSMO-4.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.space-travel.com/reports/Boeing_To_Launch_Fourth_EO_Satellite_For_Italy_999.html |title=Boeing To Launch Fourth EO Satellite For Italy |publisher=SpaceDaily |date=Dec 23, 2008}}</ref> Launched from Vandenberg Air Force Base on November 5, 2010 at 1920L.
== Ground segment == The [[ground segment]] of the system is composed of: *Command Center: **{{flag|Italy|name=Italian}} Centro Controllo e Pianificazione Missione del Fucino *Tracking and data stations: **{{flag|Argentina|name=Argentine}} Cordoba station **{{flag|Sweden}} Kiruna station *User Ground Segments: **{{flag|Italy|name=Italian}} Matera Civil User Ground Segment **{{flag|Italy|name=Italian}} Pratica di Mare Defence User Ground Segment **{{flag|France}} Defence User Ground Segment
The Argentinian and the French governments are involved respectively in the civil and military segments of the system.
==SAR capabilities== The COSMO-SkyMed satellites have three basic types of imaging modes: * Spotlight, a high-resolution mode collected over a small area by steering the radar beam slightly fore-to-aft during the collection period. * Stripmap, a medium-resolution mode collected over long, continuous swaths in which the beam is pointed broadside to the satellite track. * ScanSAR, a low-resolution mode that creates extra-wide swaths by collecting short segments at different ranges and then mosaicking them together.
There are two Spotlight modes: * SPOTLIGHT1, which is a military-only mode, and * SPOTLIGHT2, which provides a resolution of 1 m over a 10 km x 10 km area. Spotlight polarization is limited to either HH or VV
There are two Stripmap modes: * HIMAGE, which provides a resolution of between 3 and 5 m over a swath of 40 km, and * PINGPONG, which collects dual-polarization data at 15 m resolution over a swath of 30 km. The dual-polarization data can consist of any two polarizations (HH, VV, VH, HV), and it is non-coherent, as it is collected in "pulse groups" that alternate from one polarization to the other.
There are two ScanSAR modes: * WIDEREGION, which provides 30 m resolution data over a swath of 100 km, and * HUGEREGION, which provides 100 m resolution data over a swath of 200 km.
The system is sized to collect up to 450 images per satellite per day.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.e-geos.it/products/cosmo.html | title = eGEOS COSMO-SkyMed Overview | publisher = eGEOS}}</ref>
==Commercialization== [[eGEOS]], S.p.A. has the exclusive worldwide commercial rights to sell COSMO-SkyMed data and products.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.e-geos.it/products/cosmo.html | title = eGEOS: COSMO-SkyMed Overview | publisher = eGEOS}}</ref>
==Flares==
The COSMO-SkyMed satellites are lesser-known deliverers of [[satellite flare]]s, sometimes approaching magnitude â3. Flares come mainly from SAR-panels of the satellites. Although overshadowed by the [[Iridium satellite constellation|Iridium satellites]], the flares are often long-lasting, with the satellites traversing much of the sky at brighter-than-average magnitudes.
<gallery> Image:COSMO_Skymed_flare.PNG|A COSMO-SkyMed flare. </gallery>
== See also == *[[SAR Lupe]], a system of five military SAR-satellites of [[Germany]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.cosmo-skymed.it/en/index.htm COSMO-SkyMed Web Site] * [http://www.e-geos.it/products/cosmo.html COSMO-SkyMed Products] * [http://www.consorzio-innova.com/ INNOVA Consorzio per l'Informatica e la Telematica s.r.l.] â Italian SME with specific know-how and expertise with COSMO-SkyMed's HDF5 format * [http://www.difesa.it/backoffice/upload/allegati/2009/%7B8752257A-EDE5-408A-9302-09683DD61291%7D.pdf Remote Monitoring of Migrants Vessels in the Mediterranean Sea (CeMiSS)]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} File pdf

revision.text:
[[Image:Rose hydrangea calla wedding bouquet.jpg|thumb|Rose, hydrangea and calla wedding bouquet]] [[Image:Flower garland sellers outside Banke Bihari Temple, Vrindavan.jpg|thumb|Garland sellers outside [[Banke Bihari Temple]], [[Vrindavan]], India]] [[Image:Chá»£ hoa táº¿t.jpg|thumb|A flower market in Vietnam]] [[Image:Fluorescent flower display.jpg|thumb|Flower display in a US supermarket]] '''Cut flowers''' are [[flower]]s or [[flower bud]]s (often with some [[Plant stem|stem]] and [[leaf]]) that have been cut from the plant bearing it. It is usually removed from the plant for decorative use. Typical uses are in [[vase]] displays, [[wreath]]s and [[garland]]s. Many gardeners harvest their own cut flowers from domestic gardens, but there is a significant [[floral industry]] for cut flowers in most countries. The plants cropped vary by climate, culture and the level of wealth locally. Often the plants are raised specifically for the purpose, in field or glasshouse growing conditions. Cut flowers can also be harvested from the wild.
The cultivation and trade of flowers is a specialization in [[horticulture]], specifically [[floriculture]].
==Uses==
A common use is for [[floristry]], usually for decoration inside a house or building. Typically the cut flowers are placed in a vase. A number of similar types of decorations are used, especially in larger buildings and at events such as weddings. These are often decorated with additional foliage. In some cultures, a major use of cut flowers is for worship; this can be seen especially in south and southeast [[Asia]].
Sometimes the flowers are picked rather than cut, without any significant leaf or stem. Such flowers may be used for wearing in hair, or in a button-hole. Masses of flowers may be used for sprinkling, in a similar way to [[confetti]].
[[Garland]]s, [[wreath]]s and [[flower bouquet|bouquet]]s are major derived and value added products.
==Longevity==
Once flowers are removed from the [[plant]] they continue to grow slowly, but have a diminished capability of receiving the [[nutrients]] that are vital for their survival. In most countries, cut flowers are a local crop because of their perishable nature. In India, much of the product has a shelf life of only a day. Among these are [[marigold (common)|marigold]] flowers for garlands and temples, which are typically harvested before dawn, and discarded after use the same day.
The majority of cut flowers can be expected to last several days with proper care. This generally requires standing them in water in shade. They can be treated in various ways to increase their life. According to James C. Schmidt, a [[Horticulture|horticulturist]] at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|University of Illinois]], originally putting cut flowers in a [[Sterilization (microbiology)|sterilized]] vase is important to extending the life of the flowers. Vases can be cleaned using a household dish detergent or a combination of water and [[bleach]]. Using these [[disinfectants]] ensures that there will be less [[bacteria]] growing within the vase that could potentially cause the plant to [[wilting|wilt]] and die at a faster rate. Schmidt also claims that cutting the flowers diagonally with a sharp knife under running water ensures that they can immediately take up fresh and clean water. Re-cutting the [[Plant stem|stems]] periodically will ensure that there is a fresh surface from which the stems can take up water. This will allow the flowers to last even longer. Other ways to care for vase flowers includes keeping flowers away from ceiling fans and air-conditioning vents as this can lead to [[dehydration]], keeping flowers away from fresh fruit of vegetables, using filtered water rather than tap water so as to avoid both [[chlorine]] and [[Fluoride in water|fluoride]], and keeping flowers away from your television<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://lilysflorist.com.au/caring-for-your-flowers|title=Tips On How To Care For Your Flowers Once Delivered|website=messages.website-name|language=en|access-date=2017-11-06}}</ref>.
There is also a market for 'everlasting' or dried flowers, which include species such as [[Xerochrysum bracteatum]]. These can have a very long shelf life.
===Additives=== According to the [[Brooklyn Botanical Garden]], different additives can be used to prolong the lives of fresh cut flowers. Experiments were performed with various substances mixed with water, including [[aspirin]], [[multivitamin|vitamin pills]], [[vinegar]], [[pennies]], and flower food to test their effect on cut flowers' lifespans.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ngrguardiannews.com/index.php?option=com_content&id=88662%3Afloristry-cut-flowers&Itemid=474|title= Additives for cut flowers}}</ref> Each plant was placed in the same environment and the same type of plant was used in each vase.
This research found that the best additive for flowers was the retailer-provided "flower food" that is usually given with a bouquet. Plants are known to thrive in an environment where there are few bacteria, plenty of food for [[energy (biology)|energy]], and water uptake is encouraged. Flower foods contain an [[acidifier]] that helps to adjust the water's [[pH]]. With a lower pH the water and food conducting system within the flower can work at maximum efficiency. The [[sugar]] in the food will be used by the plant as an energy source, which had been lost when the flower was cut away from its root. With these [[nutrient]]s the plant will be able to fully develop. Finally, there are stem unpluggers that will make sure that the flower can easily take up water and nutrients that can later be used to take care of the needs of the rest of the plant.<ref name=" Additives for cut flowers ">Additives for cut flowers</ref> This combination gives the fresh cut flowers everything that they need to survive longer. When tests were carried out in St. Mary's College C.S.S.p, Rathmines, Dublin, however, results showed that glucose was more effective at prolonging the life of cut flowers than the commercial plant food. The experiment was carried out as part of the Junior Certificate Science Examination set by the Irish State Examinations Commission 2008.
==Trade==
The largest producers are, in order of cultivated area, China, India, and the United States. The largest importer and exporter by value is the Netherlands, which is both a grower and a redistributor of crops imported from other countries. Most of its exports go to its European neighbours.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/public/english/dialogue/sector/papers/ctflower/index.htm |title=Sectoral Activities Department (SECTOR) |publisher=Ilo.org |date= |accessdate=2011-12-05}}</ref><ref>http://www.foodnet.cgiar.org/market/Uganda/reports/Roses.PDF</ref>
In recent decades, with the increasing use of [[air freight]], it has become economic for high value crops to be grown far from their point of sale; the market is usually in industrialised countries. Typical of these is the production of [[rose]]s in Ecuador and Colombia, mainly for the US market, and production in Kenya and Uganda for the European market. Some countries specialise in especially high value products, such as [[orchid]]s from Singapore and Thailand.
As with the production of fruit and vegetables, the industry depends on significant amounts of water, which may be collected and stored by the farm owners. The [[Patel Dam failure]] in May 2018, associated with a large Kenyan rose farm, killed dozens of people.
The total market value in most countries is considerable. It has been estimated at approximately GBP 2 billion in the United Kingdom, of the same order as that of music sales.<ref>{{cite news|author=Gardening |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/gardening/3343543/Country-roses-A-cut-above.html |title=Country roses: A cut above |publisher=Telegraph |date= 2007-07-13|accessdate=2011-12-05 |location=London}}</ref>
==Further reading== *ArbelÃ¡ez, MarÃ­a AngÃ©lica , Marcela MelÃ©ndez, and NicolÃ¡s LeÃ³n"The Emergence of Fresh Cut-Flower Exports in Colombia" In ''Export Pioneers in Latin America'' Edited by Charles Sabel et al., Baltimore: Inter-American Development Bank 2012. *Austin, James E. 1990. ''Cut Flower Industry in Colombia'' (Abridged). Boston: Harvard Business School. *Encinales, Felipe, and James E. Austin. 1990. "The Cut Flower Industry in Colombia". In James E. Austin with TomÃ¡s O. Kohn, ''Strategic Management in Developing Countries: Case Studies''. New York: The Free Press 1990. *Goody, Jack. ''The culture of flowers''. Cambridge University Press, *{{cite web|year=2017|url=http://www.worldatlas.com/articles/global-leaders-in-cut-flower-exports.html|title=Global Leaders In Cut Flower Exports|quote=Though its dominance has somewhat waned over the past decade, the Netherlands still dominates this market sector.|publisher=worldatlas.com}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.bbg.org/gardening/article/cut-flower_care/ Cut-Flower Care â How to Make Your Fresh-Cut Flowers Last] by Rose G. Edinger, Brooklyn Botanical Garden, Spring 2003, retrieved October 21, 2006 * [http://www.omniflora.com/e-tips.htm Omniflora] [[Category:Horticulture and gardening]]

[[Image:Edsviken 1865.jpg|thumb|''Utsikt Ã¶ver Edsviken'' (View of Edsviken) by [[Johan Christoffer Boklund]], 1865]] '''Edsviken''' is an elongated, narrow [[inlet]] of the [[Baltic Sea]] running through the [[Sweden|Swedish]] municipalities of [[Danderyd Municipality|Danderyd]], [[Solna Municipality|Solna]] and [[Sollentuna Municipality|Sollentuna]] in [[Stockholm County]]. Edsviken ranges from [[Stocksund]] and [[Bergshamra, Solna]] in the south to [[Edsberg, Sollentuna|Edsberg]] in the north. The inlet is about {{convert|7.7|km|mi|abbr=on}} long with an area of approximately {{convert|3.6|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}; its maximum depth is around {{convert|20|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}}. The Edsviken joins the [[Stocksundet]] at Bergshamra and eventually flows into the [[Lilla VÃ¤rtan]].
The Edsviken is a popular waterway, it is used by [[Angling|anglers]], boat owners and bathers in the summer and [[Ice skating|ice skaters]] in the winter.
With its [[brackish water]], the Edsviken offers a unique environment for its [[flora]] and [[fauna]]. Various coastal and wetland plants grow around the Edsviken, including [[Myosotis scorpioides|water forget-me-not]]—a rare plant in Sweden—''[[Bolboschoenus maritimus]]'' and [[seaweed]]. The [[Eurasian oystercatcher]] and the [[barnacle goose]] both nest on the Edsviken, which also has a wide variety of fish species, including: [[perch]], [[Carp bream|bream]], [[Northern pike|pike]], [[ruffe]], [[zander]] and the occasional [[herring]].
The Edsviken's waterside is only partially developed. Waterfront buildings include the [[Danderyds sjukhus]], [[Ulriksdal Palace]], the Sollentuna [[hill fort]], [[Kevinge gÃ¥rd]] and [[Stockholm golf club]]. The southwestern portion forms part of the [[Royal National City Park]].
{{coord|59|25|19|N|17|59|15|E|region:SE|display=title}} {{Commons category|Edsviken}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Ernest de Koven Leffingwell | image = Leffingwell cropped.JPG | birth_date = {{birth date|1875|1|13|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Knoxville, Illinois]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1971|1|27|1875|1|13|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Carmel, California]] | nationality = American | field = Geology | work_institution = Independent; US Geological Survey | alma_mater = [[University of Chicago]]; [[Trinity College, Hartford]] | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | known_for = mapping and geology of Alaska North Slope | prizes = [[Charles P. Daly Medal]] <small>(1922)</small> | footnotes = }}
'''Ernest de Koven Leffingwell''' (January 13, 1875{{spaced ndash}}January 27, 1971) was an arctic explorer, geologist and SpanishâAmerican War veteran.
During the period from 1906 to 1914, Leffingwell spent 9 summers and 6 winters on the Arctic coast of Alaska, making 31 trips by dog sled and/or small boats.<ref name="nrhpinv2"/> He created the first accurate map of a large part of the Alaskan arctic coastline. He was the first to scientifically describe [[permafrost]] and to pose theories about permafrost which have largely proven true. He accurately identified the oil potential of the North Slope region of Alaska.<ref name="nrhpinv2"/>
==Biography== [[File:Ejnar Mikkelsen 1906 lek00244.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Staff of the Anglo-American Polar Expedition (1906): Ernest de Koven Leffingwell (left), Captain Ejnar Mikkelsen, G. P. Howe, Ejnar Ditlevsen]] Ernest de Koven Leffingwell was born January 13, 1875, in [[Knoxville, Illinois]], to [[Charles Wesley Leffingwell|Charles]] and Elizabeth (nÃ©e Francis) Leffingwell. He attended the grammar school at [[Racine College]], then attended [[Trinity College, Hartford]], Connecticut, where he was captain of the track team his senior year, graduated with the AB degree in 1895 and was awarded a MA in 1900. He studied physics and geology at the [[University of Chicago]] 1896 to 1898 and 1900 to 1906. He played on the [[Chicago Maroons football]] team. Leffingwell had passed his preliminary examination and was a doctoral candidate when he left for Alaska in 1906, but apparently did not complete the degree.{{#tag:ref| University of Chicago Bulletin did not list the degree.<ref>University of Chicago [https://books.google.com/books?id=31IyAQAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Register of Doctors of Philosophy, University of Chicago, June 1893 â December i921''] ''Bulletin of Information 22'' (4) May 1922</ref> There is no thesis or dissertation in the University of Chicago library, nor did Leffingwell list the degree in 1917. Herringshaw's<ref>Herringshaw, T.W. [https://books.google.com/books?id=gRQ9AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA511&lpg=PA511&dq=Ernest+de+Koven+Leffingwell+Herringshaws&source=bl&ots=sviG4eFc7u&sig=7JQ6QiTSmxFQ6mc_H237fnRl3n4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=qwRjUbjbNMSIrAHBzoGACg&ved=0CDsQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Ernest%20de%20Koven%20Leffingwell%20Herringshaws&f=false "Leffingwell, Ernest De Koven"] ''Herringshaw's National Library of American Biography'', American Publishers Association, 1914, p. 511]</ref> (1914) and the identical entry in Men of Mark (1916)<ref name="Men of Mark" /> appear to have listed the degree in error. Leffingwell's father also has an entry in Herringshaw's.|group=n}} He taught science at St Alban's school in Knoxville, Illinois in 1895â96 and 1903â04, in the latter period also serving as Superintendent. During the [[SpanishâAmerican War]] he served as a Seaman on the US battleship [[USS Oregon (BB-3)|''Oregon'']] during its celebrated dash around [[Cape Horn]] and in the [[Battle of Santiago de Cuba|Battle of Santiago]].<ref name="Men of Mark">[https://books.google.com/books?id=O-QDAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA156&dq=Ernest+deKoven+Leffingwell&hl=en&ei=FmXcTP6oIdCNnQeM_80W&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAzgo#v=onepage&q=Ernest%20deKoven%20Leffingwell&f=false "Ernest DeKoven Leffingwell"] ''One thousand American men of mark today'' American Men of Mark, New York, 1916</ref><ref name="obit">"Obituaries" "Ernest deKoven Leffingwell" ''[[Polar Record]] 16'' (101) pp. 282â83, 1971</ref><ref name="phi upsilon">Phi Upsilon Fraternity (1917) [https://books.google.com/books?id=iCN-AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA642&lpg=PA642&dq=Ernest+De+koven+Leffingwell&source=bl&ots=ws67tFCyt2&sig=bYjMRqYrJIzcqufPEIKiZsa3dA8&hl=en&ei=hhffTIOiFYKfnAfex-idDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CD8Q6AEwCDgU#v=onepage&q=Ernest%20De%20koven%20Leffingwell&f=false ''The twelfth general Catalogue of the Psi Upsilon Fraternity''] p642</ref><ref name=Trinity>Ernest deKoven Leffingwell Alumni Folder, Trinity College Archives, Trinity College, Hartford, Connecticut.</ref><ref name="Record">''The University Record (University of Chicago) v11'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=YsAPAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA40&dq=%22Leffingwell+a+candidate+for+the%22&hl=en&ei=RLngTPSIOIefnAeLkPjFDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Leffingwell%20a%20candidate%20for%20the%22&f=false p 40], 1907</ref><ref name="Chicago">[https://books.google.com/books?id=OLMiAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA69&lpg=PA69&dq=Leffingwell+chicago+football&source=bl&ots=gGi__PSpRt&sig=8jqTr9mSM0z9X7XM4tNVHbNeyhk&hl=en&ei=x43gTKbbG8e9nAf2xtneDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CDEQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=Leffingwell&f=false "Events and Comment" "'Leff', Polar Bearer"] ''University of Chicago Magazine 7'' (3) January 1915. p 69.</ref>
He led the science staff in the 1901 [[Baldwin-Ziegler North Pole Expedition|Baldwin-Ziegler Polar Expedition]], which failed in its attempt to reach the [[North Pole]] from [[Franz Josef Land]].<ref name="nrhpinv2" /> On this expedition, he became friends with Danish explorer [[Ejnar Mikkelsen]]. Subsequently, the two raised funds for their own expedition. Leffingwell's father, who had become wealthy from his ownership of a fruit ranch in California, contributed $5000, and Mikkelsen raised a comparable amount in England and New York. Their venture became the [[Anglo-American Polar Expedition]] of 1906â1908 which aimed to explore the [[Beaufort Sea]]. At that time, many experts believed than an [[Keenan Land|undiscovered land mass]] lay in this region, since such a mass could account for observed patterns of arctic currents and tides.<ref name="obit" /><ref name="Mills">Mills, William James (2003) [https://books.google.com/books?id=PYdBH4dOOM4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=ISBN+978-1-57607-422-0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=jKS3UqTEMeHsyQH-hYAg&ved=0CFYQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=Mikkelsen&f=false "Mikkelsen, Ejnar (1880â1971)"] ''Exploring polar frontiers: a historical encyclopedia, Volume 1'' pp 426 ff, ABC-CLIO {{ISBN|1-57607-422-6}}, {{ISBN|978-1-57607-422-0}}</ref><ref name="EDKL 1915a">Leffingwell 1915a</ref> The underfunded expedition fared badly but achieved some positive results. No new land was discovered, but they delineated part of the continental shelf and Leffingwell began his mapping efforts. Their ship, the ''[[Duchess of Bedford]]'', was locked in pack ice and destroyed, but they salvaged the wood to build a cabin which Leffingwell used intermittently through 1914. Mikkelsen returned to the US in 1907, but Leffingwell remained on the arctic coast for another year. He returned to the North Slope 1909â1912 and 1913â1914, working with one assistant to map 250 km of the arctic coast, and the [[Canning River (Alaska)|Canning River]] valley .<ref name="nrhpinv2" /><ref name="obit" /><ref name="EDKL 1915a" /> [[File:Leffingwell dwelling and sheds circa 1910.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Leffingwell's base on Flaxman Island, circa 1910]] After spending a year and a half writing up his results at the [[United States Geological Survey]] in Washington, Leffingwell retired to Whittier, California, listing his occupation in 1917 as citriculturist. He moved to [[Carmel, California]] about 20 years later. When he died in 1971, he was believed to have been the oldest surviving polar explorer.<ref name="nrhpinv2" /><ref name="obit" /><ref name="phi upsilon" />
==Leffingwell camp site== The [[Leffingwell Camp Site]] located on a remote barrier island off Alaska, was declared a [[National Historic Landmark]] in 1978.<ref name="nrhpinv2">{{Cite journal|title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory-Nomination: Leffingwell Camp|url={{NHLS url|id=71001093}} |format=pdf|date=September 18, 1987 |author=Susan Morton |publisher=National Park Service}} and {{NHLS url|id=71001093|title=''Accompanying 12 photos from 1909, 1971, 1975.''|photos=y}} {{small|(3.47 MB)}}</ref><ref name="nhlsum">{{cite web|url=http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=1189&ResourceType=Site|title=Leffingwell Camp Site|accessdate=2008-01-05|work=National Historic Landmark summary listing|publisher=National Park Service|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511184811/http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=1189&ResourceType=Site|archivedate=2011-05-11|df=}}</ref>
==Honors== Leffingwell was awarded the Patron's Medal by the Royal Geographical Society and the Charles P. Daly Medal by the American Geographical Society, both in 1922. He was awarded an honorary Doctor of Science degree by Trinity College in 1923.<ref name="Trinity"/> Leffingwell Fork, a stream on Alaska's North Slope, Leffingwell Ridge (Brooks Range) in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, Leffingwell Glacier in the Romanzoff Mountains of the Brooks Range, Leffingwell Crags in Canada's Northwest Territories, and Leffingwell Nunatak in Greenland are named for him.
==Publications== * SR Capps and EDK Leffingwell (1904) [https://books.google.com/books?id=-NcGAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA706&dq=Leffingwell&lr=&client=firefox-a&cd=90#v=onepage&q=Leffingwell&f=false "Pleistocene Geology of the Sawatch Range near Leadville Colo"] ''The Journal of Geology 12'', NovâDec pp 698â706. * Ernest de Koven Leffingwell (1908) [https://books.google.com/books?id=Y5KIAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA56&lpg=PA56&dq=Ernest+De+koven+Leffingwell&source=bl&ots=UyJIcIUaq7&sig=NxE9uMJpHLnsiemkaeM388ZqSbM&hl=en&ei=nRPfTIffFIjDnAf88YSTDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEIQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=Ernest%20De%20koven%20Leffingwell&f=false "Flaxman Island a glacial remnant"] ''Journal of Geology 16'' (1) pp. 56â63 * Ernest de Koven Leffingwell (1915a) [https://books.google.com/books?id=OLMiAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA69&lpg=PA69&dq=Leffingwell+chicago+football&source=bl&ots=gGi__PSpRt&sig=8jqTr9mSM0z9X7XM4tNVHbNeyhk&hl=en&ei=x43gTKbbG8e9nAf2xtneDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CDEQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=Leffingwell&f=false "A communication from Leffingwell"] ''University of Chicago Magazine 7'' (3) January 1915, pp 76â79. Leffingwell's short popular account, written for the alumni magazine. See also page 69. * Ernest de K. Leffingwell (1915b) [https://books.google.com/books?id=gtIGAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA635&dq=Ground-ice+wedges,+the+dominant&hl=en&ei=QVTgTLeNEYGWnAf6-ZnSDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Ground-ice%20wedges%2C%20the%20dominant&f=false "Ground-ice wedges, the dominant form of ground-ice on the north coast of Alaska"] ''Journal of Geology 23'', pp 635â654. * Ernest de K. Leffingwell (1919) [https://books.google.com/books?id=LG7nAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_atb#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The Canning River Region, Northern Alaska''] Professional paper 109, United States Geological Survey, Govt. print. off., Washington (also at Hathi Trust [http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001038754]) * Ernest de Koven Leffingwell (1961) "My Polar Explorations, 1901â1914", ''Explorers Journal 39'', 2â14

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=November 2016}} '''Frank Skeffington Carroll''' (c. 1837â1887)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cityofadelaide.org/wiki/Hogarth_Family_-_F19125|title=Hogarth Family â F19125|author=J. K. Stokes|publisher=Paxwiki (City of Adelaide clipper ship)|accessdate=25 August 2013}}</ref> was a salesman, mapmaker, journalist, editor, and, briefly, politician in the colony of South Australia.
Carroll was born in Ireland, the second son of Bernard Carroll of [[Dublin]].
He emigrated to Australia, perhaps around 1870, and had a chequered career in Victoria and New South Wales.
Around 1875, as "Frank O'Reilly" he was a popular society figure in Tasmania, and left that colony owing money to investors in Hiscock & Co.'s "Map of Tasmania", in which he had a stake, and which was never published.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article149824533 |title=A Gay Adventurer |newspaper=[[Geelong Advertiser]] |location=Vic. |date=10 May 1878 |accessdate=24 August 2015 |page=3 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
In 1876 he was a candidate for the South Australian House of Assembly seat of [[Electoral district of Sturt (South Australia)|Sturt]]. He took over as proprietor and editor of ''The Lantern'', a satirical weekly,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article110489542 |title=The Wallaroo Times. |newspaper=[[The Wallaroo Times and Mining Journal]] |location=Port Wallaroo, SA |date=19 April 1876 |accessdate=24 August 2015 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> with Alfred Clint, scenic artist of the [[Theatre Royal, Adelaide|Theatre Royal]], his cartoonist.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article64324729 |title=Knocking About |newspaper=[[The Register (Adelaide)]] |volume=XCI, |issue=26,558 |location=South Australia |date=9 February 1926 |accessdate=3 September 2017 |page=11 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> He published an atlas of South Australia late in this same year (see Bibliography below).
He was elected to one of three seats for the district of [[Electoral district of Light|Light]] in the [[South Australian House of Assembly|House of Assembly]] in April 1878, despite public accusations that he had spent time in [[Pentridge prison]], which he strenuously denied.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article42997126 |title=The General Elections, District of Light |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=1 April 1878 |accessdate=24 August 2015 |page=6 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> It turned out the accusations were "[[straw men]]" set up by himself or a friend: he had not used the alias "O'Sullivan" in New Zealand, and had not been sent to Pentridge, but he '''had''' called himself "O'Reilly" in Tasmania, and '''had''' been sent to [[Melbourne Gaol]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article42989702 |title=Mr. F. S. Carroll |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=29 April 1878 |accessdate=25 August 2015 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> After the ''[[South Australian Register|Register]]'' revealed that Carroll had been sentenced to two years' in [[Darlinghurst Gaol]] for uttering a valueless cheque, citing the ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'' of 22 August 1871,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13243545 |title=Forging and Uttering a Cheque |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=22 August 1871 |accessdate=24 August 2015 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Carroll was forced to resign his seat in May 1878.
He was tried by Judge Boucaut and jury for malicious libel in ''The Lantern'' of 23 August 1879 against James Hurst and the Mutual Trade Protection Association. Carroll defended himself without distinction, was found guilty and sentenced to six months' jail and a fine of Â£500.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article60096525 |title=South Australia |newspaper=[[Illustrated Australian News]] |location=Melbourne |date=31 October 1879 |accessdate=24 August 2015 |page=174 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Duncan Moodie, editor of ''[[The Portonian]]'', another Adelaide satirical paper, described Carroll as having "a hide like a rhinoceros" and producing "an effete and harmless paper". Carroll made various attempts to improve ''The Lantern'': in 1881 he and partner John Roche enlarged it to [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]] format, included serious articles by F. H. Linklater and Henry Cargill, and dropped the cartoons. Roche died at the end of 1881 and publication lapsed for six months before reappearing in its old format. In July 1882 Carroll was charged with republishing an article from ''Pasquin'' without permission.<ref name=SAM/>
Carroll sold the paper to Charles F. Stansbury, who with Charles A. Murphy in 1884 took over and absorbed [[Adelaide Punch]]. In 1890 The Lantern was taken over by [[Quiz (Adelaide newspaper)|Quiz]].<ref name=SAM>{{cite web|url=http://www.samemory.sa.gov.au/site/page.cfm?c=3621|title=SA Memory:''The Lantern''|accessdate=24 August 2015}}</ref>
He died in Melbourne.
==Family== He married Emma Hogarth, nÃ©e Homburg, (c. 1844 â ) of Adelaide on 28 April 1877.

S. (Frank Skeffington) | author2=South Australian Genealogy and Heraldry Society | title=The New counties, hundreds and district atlas of South Australia and Northern Territory together with map of South Australia, indicating roads, distances, relative position of counties, etc., etc | publication-date=1986 | publisher=South Australian Genealogy and Heraldry Society | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/6602223 | accessdate=24 August 2015 }}
