revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=January 2016}}
'''Lerappa''' ("Apparel" spelled backwards) is the private island that was commissioned by [[American Apparel]] in [[Second Life]] to emulate the company's real world stores in the real world. The store was designed by virtual content designer Aimee Weber and was completed and opened in Second Life on June 17 of 2006. American Apparel pulled out of Second Lifeâs virtual arena and closed virtual shop in the fourth quarter of 2007.<ref name=apress>{{cite web |url=http://www.americanapparel.net/presscenter/secondlife/ |title=Sorry, We're Closed. |accessdate=2008-04-28 |author= |date=2007-02-27 |work= |publisher=American Apparel Inc |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080515210103/http://www.americanapparel.net/presscenter/secondlife/ |archivedate=2008-05-15 |df= }}</ref>
==Building Design==
Designer Aimee Weber had designed other projects in Second Life for large clients, with approval of members in the Second Life world.{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} Lerappa's {{convert|6000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} two-story company store was modeled after American Apparel's Tokyo showroom, and included some of the controversial advertising campaigns on the walls around the store.<ref name="sec">{{cite web|url=http://secondlife.com/newsletter/2006_06/html/developer.html |title=American Apparel Breaks New Ground |accessdate=2008-04-28 |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Linden Research, Inc |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080402105413/http://secondlife.com/newsletter/2006_06/html/developer.html |archivedate=2008-04-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name=street>{{cite web |url=http://www.thestreet.com/story/10318273/1/american-apparel-finds-the-right-fit-in-second-life.html |title=American Apparel Finds the Right Fit in Second Life |accessdate=2008-04-28 |author=Robert Holden |date=2006-10-27 |work= |publisher=TheStreet.com}}</ref> The building was constructed in mostly glass and featured lighting that change when the virtual world reaches night time.<ref name=sec/> Outside the store was a stage where live virtual bands can perform.<ref name=sec/> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Cc aa3.jpg|thumb|175px|left|American Apparel's Second Life Facility]] -->
==Merchandising==
Official American Apparel clothing, along with planned new lines the company was [[test marketing]],<ref name=bweek/> was purchased in virtual form for less than 266 Linden (approximately US$1) and included a discount code usable at the company's real-life online store.<ref name=bweek>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/innovate/content/jun2006/id20060627_217800.htm |title=American Apparel's Virtual Clothes |accessdate=2008-04-28 |author=Reena Jana |date=2006-06-24 |work= |publisher=BusinessWeek.com}}</ref> 20 of American Apparelâs styles were offered initially,<ref name=style>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/technology/2006/06/14/american-apparel-retail_cz_ph_0614secondlife.html |title=Online Shopping|accessdate=2008-04-28 |author=Patricia Huang |date=2006-06-14 |work= |publisher=Forbes.com}}</ref> Customers could also purchase real clothing from the company website via the virtual store.<ref name=street/>
==Marketing== Lerappa was intended as an advertising experiment more than a vehicle for electronic commerce.<ref name=style/> In its first ten days of operation it generated approximately as much revenue as a typical retail location's daily sales.<ref name=bweek/>
==Virtual Protests==
Second Life protesters (aka. [http://secondlla.googlepages.com/ Second Life Liberation Army]) held a virtual protest opposing the companyâs real world use of sexually suggestive imagery in advertising campaigns. In February 2007 the virtual location was attacked by "virtual terrorists" via "white balls" which purposely placed in the store<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,22161037-28737,00.html | work=The Australian | title=Virtual terrorists | date=2007-07-31}}</ref> to temporarily obstruct areas of the screen.
==References== {{reflist|}}

{{fict-location-stub}}

==Other== * [[Nancy Andrew]] â translator, junior year, 1967â1968 * [[Yuji Horii]] â video game designer * [[Yoshio Shirai]] * [[Tensai Okamura]] â director * [[Tomonobu Itagaki]] â video game designer, School of Law, 1985â92 * [[:ja:è¾»éé|Shizuo Tsuji]] * [[Kyohei Sakaguchi]] * [[Einosuke Akiya]] â 5th President of [[Soka Gakkai]] * [[Akihito Hirose]] - [[Professional shogi player]], former [[Åi (shogi)|Åi]] title holder. * [[Taichi Nakamura]] - [[Professional shogi player]], current [[Åza (shogi)|Åza]] title holder.
==Notable current students== ===Sports=== * [[Yuzuru Hanyu]] â figure Skater, 2014, 2018 Winter Olympics gold medalist * [[Tatsuki Machida]] â figure skater * [[Miyabi Onitsuka]] â snowboarder * [[Kanako Watanabe]] â swimmer * [[Ippei Watanabe (swimmer)|Ippei Watanabe]] â swimmer
===Performing arts=== * [[Jyongri]] â singer * [[Natsuki Sato]] â idol singer, former member of [[AKB48]] * [[Yui Ogura]] â voice actor, roles include Toki OnjÅji ([[Saki Achiga-hen Episode of Side-A]])
==Notable faculty members== * ''[[Yaichi Aizu]]'', poet, scholar of ancient Chinese and Japanese art, and namesake of Aizu Museum * [[Tameyuki Amano]], economics scholar and educator * ''Yasunobu Fujiwara'', scholar of [[political science]] * [[Lafcadio Hearn]], novelist, literary scholar, professor of [[English literature]] * ''Smimasa Idditti (Sumimasa Idichi )'', professor of English * ''[[Kenji Imai (architect)|Kenji Imai]]'', architect * ''Tokio Kimura'', historian * [[Kume Kunitake|Kunitake Kume]], historian * [[Tachu Naito]], architect * ''Naoyoshi Nakamura'', historian * ''Haruo Nishihara'', law professor, former President * ''[[Takayasu Okushima]]'', law professor, former President * Hajime Ånishi, philosopher * ''[[Ikuo Oyama|Ikuo Åyama]]'', scholar of political science * ''Yaso Saijo'', poet * ''Masasada Shiozawa'', scholar of economics, former President * Sanae Takata, scholar of political science, former President * ÅdÅ Tanaka, philosopher * [[Shoyo Tsubouchi]], playwright, critic, [[translator]], educator, professor of English literature, and namesake of Tsubouchi Memorial Theater Museum * ''Sokichi Tsuda'', historian, recipient of the [[Order of Culture]] * Kazutami Ukita, scholar of political science * Shujiro Urata, economist * Yoshio Yamanouchi, translator, scholar of [[French literature]] * Akira Yonekura, law professor * ''[[Takamasa Yoshizaka]]'', architect
== Principals, ''de facto'' presidents (1907â1923), and presidents ==
=== Principals === * Hidemaro Åkuma, 1882â1886 * [[Maejima Hisoka|Hisoka Maejima]], 1886â1890 * [[Kazuo Hatoyama]], 1890â1907
=== ''De facto'' presidents (1907â1923) === * Sanae Takata, 1907â1915 * Tameyuki Amano, 1915â1917 * Yoshiro Hiranuma, 1918â1921 * Masasada Shiozawa, 1921â1923
=== Presidents === * Shigenobu Åkuma,<ref>as an honorary post</ref> 1907â1922 * Masasada Shiozawa, 1923 * Sanae Takata, 1923â1931 * Hozumi Tanaka (public finance scholar, Doctor of Laws, 1876â1944), 1931â1944 * Tomio Nakano, 1944â1946 * Koichi Shimada, 1946â1954 * [[Nobumoto Åhama]], 1954â1966 * Kenichi Abe, 1966â1968 * Tsunesaburo Tokikoyama, 1968â1970 * Sukenaga Murai, 1970â1978 * Tsukasa Shimizu, 1978â1982 * Haruo Nishihara, 1982â1990 * ChÅ«maru Koyama, 1990â1994 * Takayasu Okushima, 1994â2002 * Katsuhiko Shirai, 2002â2010 * Kaoru Kamata, 2010âPresent
== Trustees == * [[Ryuhoku Narushima]], poet, journalist, and one of the first trustees of Waseda * Azusa Ono (1852â1886), law scholar and one of the first trustees of Waseda
== Benefactors == Waseda University has had numerous benefactors, including: * [[Eiichi Shibusawa]],<ref>Okushima and Nakamura (eds.), p.53</ref> businessman and philanthropist * Ichizaemon Morimura,<ref>Okushima and Nakamura (eds.), p.51</ref> businessman * Koichiro Kagami,<ref>Okushima and Nakamura (eds.), p.63</ref> businessman * Kenkichi Kodera,<ref>Okushima and Nakamura (eds.), p.65</ref> presenter of over thirty-six thousand foreign books to the [[Waseda University Library|Library]] * Kisaku Maekawa,<ref>Okushima and Nakamura (eds.), p.68</ref> businessman and philanthropist * [[Masaru Ibuka]], after whom Masaru Ibuka Auditorium (Hall)<ref>Masaru Ibuka Auditorium (Hall) is in the International Conference Center.</ref> is named. * Robert J. Shillman, founder & CEO of [[Cognex Corporation]], namesake of Robert Shillman Hall
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [https://www.wasedaalumni.jp/e/ Waseda University Alumni Association (WUAA) website]

This is a '''list of cities in [[South America]]'''.
==Largest cities==
This list includes all South American cities with a population [[city proper|within city limits]] exceeding 500,000 according to official census figures, estimates or projections as of 2015, the most recent year for which official population census results, estimates or short-term projections are available for all of these cities. These figures do not reflect the population of the [[urban agglomeration]] or [[metropolitan area]] which typically do not coincide with the administrative boundaries of the city. All figures refer to the mid-2015 population. {| class="wikitable sortable" ! ! Name ! Image ! [[File:Niger Delta Basin Location.png|thumb|The Niger Delta Basin is located in the Gulf of Guinea on the west coast of Africa.]]
[[File:Niger Delta Geologic map.png|thumb|Geologic map of the Niger Delta Basin and the Benue trough, and the oil fields in the region.]]
The '''Niger Delta Basin''', also referred to as the '''Niger Delta province''', is an extensional rift basin located in the [[Niger Delta]] and the [[Gulf of Guinea]] on the passive continental margin near the western coast of Nigeria<ref name="United States Geologic Survey">{{cite web|last1=Tuttle|first1=Michele|last2=Charpentier|first2=Ronald|last3=Brownfield|first3=Michael|title=The Niger Delta Petroleum System: Niger Delta Province, Nigeria, Cameroon, and Equatorial Guinea, Africa|url=http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/1999/ofr-99-0050/OF99-50H/ChapterA.html|website=United States Geologic Survey|publisher=United States Geologic Survey|accessdate=6 March 2015}}</ref> with suspected or proven access to Cameroon, Equatorial Guinea and SÃ£o TomÃ© and PrÃ­ncipe. This basin is very complex, and it carries high economic value as it contains a very productive [[petroleum reservoir|petroleum system]]. The Niger delta basin is one of the largest subaerial basins in Africa. It has a subaerial area of about 75,000 km<sup>2</sup>, a total area of 300,000 km<sup>2</sup>, and a sediment fill of 500,000 km<sup>3</sup>.<ref name="United States Geologic Survey" /> The sediment fill has a depth between 9â12 km.<ref name="Sequence stratigraphy of the Pliocene-Pleistocene strata and shelf-margin deltas of the eastern Niger Delta, Nigeria">{{Cite thesis |last=fatoke |first=oluwaseyi adedamola |title=sequence stratigraphy of the pliocene-pleistocene strata and shelf-margin deltas of the eastern niger delta, nigeria |type=ph.d.|year=2010 |publisher=university of houston}}</ref> It is composed of several different [[geologic formations]] that indicate how this basin could have formed, as well as the regional and large scale [[tectonics]] of the area. The Niger Delta Basin is an [[extensional tectonics|extensional basin]] surrounded by many other basins in the area that all formed from similar processes. The Niger Delta Basin lies in the south westernmost part of a larger tectonic structure, the [[Benue Trough]]. The other side of the basin is bounded by the [[Cameroon Volcanic Line]] and the transform passive continental margin.<ref name="Sequence stratigraphy of the Pliocene-Pleistocene strata and shelf-margin deltas of the eastern Niger Delta, Nigeria" />
==Basin formation== The Niger Delta Basin was formed by a failed rift [[triple junction|junction]] during separation of the [[South American plate]] and the [[African plate]], as well as the opening of the South Atlantic. Rifting in this basin started in the late [[Jurassic]] and ended in the mid [[Cretaceous]]. As rifting continued, several [[Fault (geology)|faults]] formed, many of them [[thrust faults]]. Also at this time we have the deposition of the syn-rift sands and then shales in the late cretaceous. This shows that there was a regression in the early basin. By this time the basin has been undergoing extension by high angle normal faults and fault block rotation. Then at beginning of the Paleocene there was a large transgression.<ref name="Sequence stratigraphy of the Pliocene-Pleistocene strata and shelf-margin deltas of the eastern Niger Delta, Nigeria" /> Then in the Paleocene the [[Akata Formation]] was deposited. In the Eocene the [[Agbada Formation]] was deposited. This caused the underlying shale [[Akata Formation]] to be squeezed into shale diapirs. Then in the Oligocene the [[Benin formation]] was deposited and it still being deposited today. The overall basin is divided into a few different zones due to its tectonic structure.<ref name="United States Geologic Survey" /> There is an extensional zone, which lies on the continental shelf, that is caused by the thickened crust. There is a transition zone, and then there is a contraction zone, which lies in the deep sea part of the basin.
==Lithology== [[File:Niger Delta Sealevel Stand.PNG|thumb|Sealevel highstand and lowstand mapped on a crossection of the basin]]
The sediment fill in the Niger Delta basin is characterized by three major depobelts. These three cycles show that the basin experienced an overall [[marine regression|regression]] throughout time as the sediments go from deep sea mud sized grains to [[fluvial]] denser sand sized grains. The [[lithologies]] of the area experience changes due to several factors. One factor would be the types of sediment coming through the [[river delta|delta]], which could be influenced by sea level, or maybe [[volcanic]] activity in the area. The type of environment of deposition will also change the sediment type. The early Cretaceous sediments were thought to be from a tide dominated system that were deposited on a concave shoreline, and throughout time the shoreline has become convexed and it is currently a wave dominated system.
;Basement The oceanic basement rock is the oldest rock in the basin and is [[basaltic]] in composition. It is of the pre-rift time period. Also closer to the coast you have [[precambrian]] continental basement.
;Cretaceous There is a section of rock in this basin from the middle to late cretaceous that there is not much information on due to extreme depth. It is believed to be composed of sediments from a tide dominated coastline,<ref name="United States Geologic Survey" /> and there are believed to be several layers of shales, although there distribution is not known.
;Akata Formation The Akata Formation is [[Paleocene]] in age. It is composed of thick shales, turbidite sands, and small amounts of silt and clay. It is the mobile formation that is squeezed into shale diapirs in the basin that are formed form being over pressured and not being dehydrated properly. The Akata Formation formed during lowstands in sealevel and in oxygen deficient conditions. This formation is estimated to be up to 7000 meters thick.<ref name="United States Geologic Survey" />
;Agbada Formation The Agbada Formation dates back to [[Eocene]] in age. It is a marine facies defined by both freshwater and deep sea characteristics. This is the major oil and natural gas bearing facies in the basin. The hydrocarbons in this layer formed when this layer of rock became subaerial and was covered in a swamp type of environment that contained lots of organics. It is estimated to be 3700 meters thick.<ref name="United States Geologic Survey" />
;Benin Formation The Benin Formation is [[Oligocene]] and younger in age. It is composed of continental flood plain sands and alluvial deposits. It is estimated to be up to 2000 meters thick.<ref name="United States Geologic Survey" />
==Tectonic structures== [[File:Niger Delta Tectonic structure.jpg|thumb|Tectonic Structures drawn over a seismic profile of the Niger Delta Basin]] [[File:Niger Delta Mobile Shales and Subbasins.png|thumb|Evolution of Niger Delta subbasins as mobile shales migrate towards the continental slope.]]
The tectonic structures in the Niger Delta Basin are very typical of an extensional rift system, but the added shale diapirism due to compression makes this basin different. The main method of deformation is due to gravitational collapse of the basin, although the older faulting and deformation in the basin are related to the continental breakup and rifting of the African plate and South American plates.<ref name="United States Geologic Survey" /> The overall basin is divided into a few different zones due to its tectonic structure. There is an extensional zone, which lies on the continental shelf, that is caused by the thickened crust. There is a transition zone, and then there is a contraction zone, which lies in the deep sea part of the basin.
;Basin inversion Basin inversion is caused by uplift and/or compression in this basin. The compression is caused by the toe detachment of the shale diapirs. Basin inversion forms anticline structures, which serve as a great oil trap. Clay smears in the sediments seal the formations so oil does not escape out.<ref name="United States Geologic Survey" />
;Basinward dipping reflectors Basinward dipping reflectors are a common feature of extensional type rift basins. As fault blocks extend they rotate to dip towards the center of the basin. At the top of these fault blocks sub basins can form.
;Shale diapirs The shale diapirs are from the Akata Formation. This structure is formed due to the improper dehydration of the formation and the over pressuring by the overlying and denser Agbada Formation.<ref name="United States Geologic Survey" />
;High-angle normal faulting High-angle [[normal fault]]ing is a feature of the extensional portion of the rifting in this basin. It is considered a growth fault and the feature lies closer towards the basins edge and transitions to the toe detachment faulting as you continue down the basin.<ref name=AAPG>{{cite journal|last1=Short|first1=K.C.|last2=Staeuble|first2=A.J.|title=Outline of geology of Niger delta|journal=AAPG Bulletin|volume=51|issue=5|pages=761â799|doi=10.1306/5d25c0cf-16c1-11d7-8645000102c1865d }}</ref>
==Petroleum== [[File:Nigerdeltapetroleumsys.gif|thumb|Minimum and maximum petroleum system]]
The Niger Delta Basin produces around 2 million barrels of oil per day. The entire system is predicted to contain 34.5 billion barrels of oil and 94 trillion feet<sup>3</sup> of natural gas.This area is still very heavily explored by oil companies today. It is one of the largest oil producers in the world.<ref name="United States Geologic Survey" />

{{Infobox person |name = Pierre Camu |image = |alt = |caption = |birth_date = March 19, 1923 |birth_place = [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]] |death_date = |death_place = |other_names = |known_for = |occupation = |nationality = |awards = [[Order of Canada]]
[[National Order of Quebec]] }} '''Pierre Camu''', {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|OC|CQ|MSRC}} (born March 19, 1923) is a [[Canada|Canadian]] geographer, civil servant, academic, and transport executive. ==Biography== Born in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Camu received a Master of Arts degree in 1947 and a Ph.D. in [[Geography]] in 1951 from the [[UniversitÃ© de MontrÃ©al]]. From 1947 to 1949, he did his post-graduate studies at [[Johns Hopkins University]]. From 1949 to 1956, he worked with the geography branch of the Department of Mines and Technical Surveys in Ottawa. From 1956 to 1960, he was a Professor of Economic Geography at [[UniversitÃ© Laval]]. In 1960, he became Vice-President of the St. Lawrence Seaway Authority (now called [[Saint Lawrence Seaway Management Corporation]]) and was president from 1965 to 1973. From 1973 to 1977, he was president of the [[Canadian Association of Broadcasters]]. From 1977 to 1979, he was Chairman of the [[Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission]] (CRTC). From 1979 to 1984, he was president of March Shipping Company. From 1984 to 1988, he was a vice-president at Lavalin Inc. (now [[SNC Lavalin]]). From 1988 to 1992, he was Chairman of the Petroleum Monitoring Agency. In 1966, he was made a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Canada]]. In 1976, he was made an Officer of the [[Order of Canada]]. In 1998, he was made a Knight of the [[National Order of Quebec]]. In 1999, awarded the [[Camsell Medal]] by the [[Royal Canadian Geographical Society]]. ==References== * [http://utpress.utpress.utoronto.ca/cgi-bin/cw2w3.cgi?p=campeau&t=9490&d=1390 Canadian Who's Who 1997 entry] * [http://www.rcgs.org/awards/camsell_medal/previous_winners.asp Royal Canadian Geographical Society Camsell Medal winners] {{s-start}} {{s-gov}} {{s-bef|before=[[Harry J. Boyle]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Chairman]] of the [[Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission|CRTC]] |years=1977â1979}} {{s-aft|after=[[John Meisel]]}} {{end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Camu, Pierre}} [[Category:1923 births]] [[Category:Canadian geographers]] [[Category:Chairpersons of the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Canada]] [[Category:Knights of the National Order of Quebec]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of Canada]] [[Category:People from Montreal]] [[Category:UniversitÃ© de MontrÃ©al alumni]] [[Category:UniversitÃ© Laval faculty]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Massey Medal recipients]] [[Category:Johns Hopkins University alumni]]

{{essay-like|date=July 2017}} '''Place identity''' or '''place-based identity''' refers to a cluster of ideas about [[Sense of place|place]] and [[Identity (social science)|identity]] in the fields of [[geography]], [[urban planning]], [[urban design]], [[landscape architecture]], [[environmental psychology]], [[ecocriticism]] and urban sociology/ecological sociology. Place identity is sometimes called [[urban character]], [[neighbourhood character]] or local character. Place identity has become a significant issue in the last 25 years in urban planning and design. Place identity concerns the meaning and significance of places for their inhabitants and users, and how these meanings contribute to individuals' conceptualizations of self.<ref>Simandan, D. 2011. On time, place and happiness. New Zealand Geographer, 67(1), pp.6-15. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1745-7939.2011.01192.x </ref> Place identity also relates to the context of modernity, history and the politics of representation.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/45636842|title=City and nation : rethinking place and identity|last=P.|first=Smith, Michael|last2=Thomas.|first2=Bender,|date=2001|publisher=Transaction Publishers|isbn=0765808714|oclc=45636842}}</ref> In other words, [[historical determinism]], which intersects historical events, social spaces and groups by [[gender]], [[Social class|class]], [[ethnicity]].<ref name=":1" /> In this way, it explores how spaces have evolved over time by exploring the [[social constructs]] through time and the development of space, place and power.<ref name=":1" /> To the same extent, the politics of representation is brought into context, as the making of place identity in a community also relates to the exclusion or inclusion in a community. Through this, some have argued that place identity has become an area for social change because it gives [[marginalized]] communities agency{{clarify|date=June 2017}} over their own spaces.<ref name=":1" /> In the same respect, it is argued that place identity has also been used to intervene social change and perpetuate oppression from a top-down approach by creating segregated spaces for marginalized communities.<ref name=":1" />
== Place attachment and sense of place == In some ways it is related to the concepts of [[place attachment]] and [[sense of place]]. Place identity is largely related to the concepts of community formation because it recognizes that geographical spaces do not solely bond a community together but rather there are social bonds that account for community formation. Those social forces often are feelings of belonging and security, which involve theoretical formations of community.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Key Concepts in Community Studies|last=Blackshaw|first=Tony|publisher=Sage|year=2010|isbn=978-1-4129-2844-1|location=London|pages=97â123}}</ref> Theoretical formations of community, which were identified in ''Community: Seeking Safety in an Insecure World'' (Bauman, 2001) as bonds formed by similar locality, culture, language, kinship and/or experiences.<ref name=":2" /> In addition, identity also conceives feelings of security and freedom as one is able to self-identify and especially, when it comes to being able to foster agency over community formation.<ref name=":2" /> In addition, the similar and shared experiences of culture, language and locality foster the sense of community.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/872630621|title=Neighborhood as refuge : community reconstruction, place remaking, and environmental justice in the city|last=Isabelle,|first=Anguelovski,|isbn=9780262525695|oclc=872630621}}</ref> This fostering of community is largely seen as an extension of agency because when a community is able to achieve a sense of place and place attachment, this allows for individuals to reinforce their own identities and strengthen their bonds within their community.<ref name=":3" />
== Methodology == Methodologies for understanding place identity primarily involve qualitative techniques, such as interviewing, [[participant observation]], [[discourse analysis]] and mapping a range of physical elements. Some urban planners, urban designers and landscape architects use forms of [[deliberative planning]], [[design charettes]] and [[participatory design]] with local communities as a way of working with place identity to transform existing places as well as create new ones. This kind of planning and design process is sometimes referred to as [[placemaking]].
=== Case studies === The following case studies are examples of how place identity is researched on the field.
==== Cape Cod, Massachusetts ==== In a study by Lee Cuba and David M. Hummon (1993), they focus on Cape Cod, Massachusetts residents and how social and environmental factors are associated with place identity. Place identity in regards to "at-homeness" was defined by existence, affiliations, and locus. Community members were asked if they feel at home in Cape Cod to measure the positive responses for existence. The open-ended responses to why community members feel at home were used to measure place affiliation. A close-ended question, "Do you associate feeling at home with living in this particular house or apartment, with living in this community, or with living on the Cape, in general?"<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cuba|first=Lee|last2=Hummon|first2=David M.|date=1993|title=A Place to Call Home: Identification with Dwelling, Community, and Region|jstor=4121561|journal=The Sociological Quarterly|volume=34|issue=1|pages=111â131|doi=10.1111/j.1533-8525.1993.tb00133.x}}</ref> was used to measure locus. Most respondents reported they did feel "at home".
==== Michigan and the Great Lakes ==== Michigan and the Great Lakes are analyzed to see the values and connections shared within the residents of Michigan. A questionnaire was given to Michigan residents to see how attached the residents are. The questionnaire consisted of statements and the statements were evaluated through the five-point Likert scale. As a result, the data revealed "Michigan's voters have developed a strong sense of place regarding the state".<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Nanzer|first=Bruce|date=2004|title=Measuring Sense of Place: A Scale for Michigan|jstor=25610679|journal=Administrative Theory & Praxis|volume=26|issue=3|pages=362â382}}</ref>
These two case studies shows that place has a lot more to offer than just a physical location. Understanding how to measure a sense of place assist policy makers in decision making and creating potential policy implementation.<ref name=":0" /> They will take the community's issues into consideration during the planning process once they understand the values of a community.
== References == {{reflist}} {{refbegin|}}Cuba, L. & Hummon, D.M. (1993). A place to call home: Identification with dwelling, community, and region. The Sociological Quarterly, 34 (1), 111-131.
Hague, C. and Jenkins, P. (Eds) (2005). Place identity, planning and participation, London ; New York : Routledge, 2005. {{ISBN|0-415-26241-0}} (hard cover) 0415262429 (soft cover) 0203646754 (ebook)
[[Harold Proshansky|Proshansky, H. M.]] (1978). 'The city and self-identity', Journal of Environment and Behaviour, Vol. 10, pp. 57â83
Nanzer, B. (2004). Measuring sense of place: A scale of Michigan. Administrative Theory & Praxis, 26 (3), 362-382.
Proshansky, H. M., Fabian, A. K. and Kaminoff, R. (1983). 'Place-identity: Physical world socialization of the self', Journal of [[Environmental Psychology]], Vol. 3, pp. 57â83
[[Edward Relph|Relph, E]] (1976) Place and placelessness. London: Pion, 1976 ({{ISBN|0850860555}})
Roudavski, Stanislav (2008). ''[https://academia.edu/3583432/Staging_Places_as_Performances_Creative_Strategies_for_Architecture Staging Places as Performances: Creative Strategies for Architecture]'' (PhD, University of Cambridge) {{refend}}

{{about||the butterfly genus|Paramo (genus)|other uses|PÃ¡ramo (disambiguation)}} [[File:Rossettenstauden.JPG|thumb|right|PÃ¡ramo in Colombia]] '''PÃ¡ramo''' can refer to a variety of [[alpine tundra]] [[ecosystem]]s. Some ecologists describe the pÃ¡ramo broadly as "all high, tropical, montane vegetation above the continuous timberline".<ref name="Baruch"/> A more narrow term classifies the pÃ¡ramo according to its regional placement in the northern [[Andes]] of South America and adjacent southern Central America. The pÃ¡ramo is the ecosystem of the regions above the continuous forest line, yet below the permanent snowline.<ref name=Baruch>{{cite journal|last=Baruch|first=Zdravko|title=Ordination and Classification of Vegetation along an Altitudinal Gradient in the Venezuelan PÃ¡ramos|journal=Vegetation|date=20 March 1984|volume=55|series=2|pages=115â126}}</ref> It is a "[[Neotropical]] high mountain biome with a vegetation composed mainly of giant rosette plants, shrubs and grasses".<ref name="Luteyn" /> According to scientists, pÃ¡ramos may be "[[evolution|evolutionary hot spots]]" and among the fastest evolving regions on [[Earth]].<ref name="NYT-20131107">{{cite news |last=Zimmer |first=Carl |authorlink=Carl Zimmer |title=High Above Sea Level, Evolutionary Hot Spots |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/12/science/high-above-sea-level-evolutionary-hot-spots.html |date=November 7, 2013 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=November 8, 2013 }}</ref>
== Location == [[File:Paramo de Sumapaz - Yuri Romero Picon.jpg|thumb|left|[[Sumapaz Paramo|Sumapaz PÃ¡ramo]]]] The Northern Andean Paramo global ecoregion includes the [[Cordillera Central pÃ¡ramo]] (Ecuador, Peru), [[Santa Marta pÃ¡ramo]] (Colombia), [[Cordillera de Merida pÃ¡ramo]] (Venezuela) and [[Northern Andean pÃ¡ramo]] (Colombia, Ecuador) terrestrial ecoregions.<ref>{{citation|ref={{harvid|Northern Andean Paramo â WWF Global}}|title=Northern Andean Paramo|publisher=WWF Global|url=http://wwf.panda.org/about_our_earth/ecoregions/northern_andean_paramo.cfm|accessdate=2017-04-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170205181324/http://wwf.panda.org/about_our_earth/ecoregions/northern_andean_paramo.cfm|archivedate=2017-02-05|df=}}</ref> The [[Costa Rican pÃ¡ramo]] in Costa Rica and Panama is another pÃ¡ramo ecoregion. In the strictest sense of the term, all pÃ¡ramo ecosystems are located in the [[Neotropics]], specifically South and Central America. Scattered throughout the regions between [[11th parallel north|11Â°N]] and [[8th parallel south|8Â°S]] latitudes, these ecosystems are located mainly in the northwest corner of South America, in [[Colombia]], [[Ecuador]], [[Peru]], and [[Venezuela]].
In Venezuela, the pÃ¡ramo occurs in the [[Cordillera de MÃ©rida]]. PÃ¡ramo ecosystems are also found in the [[Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta]] in Colombia, and in the regions of [[Huehuetenango]] and [[El QuichÃ©]] of Guatemala in the [[Sierra de los Cuchumatanes]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Steinberg, Michael and Matthew Taylor |year=2008 |title=Guatemala's Altos de Chiantla: Changes on the High Frontier|journal=Mountain Research and Development |volume=28 |issue=3/4 |pages=255â262|issn=1994-7151 |url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/pdf/10.1659/mrd.0891 |doi=10.1659/mrd.0891}}</ref> The [[Cordillera de Talamanca]] of Costa Rica and the westernmost part of Panama has pÃ¡ramo. In northern Ecuador, the [[Guandera Biological Station]] is a fairly undisturbed pÃ¡ramo ecosystem.
The majority of the pÃ¡ramo ecosystems occur in the [[Colombian Andes]]. The [[Sumapaz PÃ¡ramo]], south of the [[Altiplano Cundiboyacense]] in the [[Cordillera Oriental (Colombia)|Eastern Ranges]] of the Colombian [[Andes]] (about {{convert|20|km|mi}} south of BogotÃ¡), is the largest pÃ¡ramo in the world. This region was declared a National Park of Colombia in 1977 because of its importance as a [[biodiversity hotspot]] and main source of water for the most densely populated area of the country, the BogotÃ¡ Savannah. The {{convert|1405|acre|km2|1|adj=on|order=flip}} PÃ¡ramo Wildlife Refuge Park in the [[San JosÃ© Province]] of Costa Rica "protects tropical forest areas in the high elevations of the [[Talamanca Mountains]]".<ref name="PÃ¡ramo Wildlife Refuge">{{cite web|title=Paramo Wildlife Refuge|url=http://www.costarica-nationalparks.com/paramowildliferefuge.html}}</ref>
[[Cotopaxi National Park]] contains {{convert|81524|acre|km2|1|order=flip}} of protected land in the [[Cotopaxi Province]] of Ecuador. Much of this park is pÃ¡ramo. Its flora includes [[Gentiana|gentians]], [[Lycopodiopsida|clubmosses]], [[valeriana|valerians]], and [[asteraceae|asters]] such as ''[[Loricaria (plant)|Loricaria]]'' and ''[[Chuquiraga]]'' species.<ref name="Planet Ecuador">{{cite web|last=Marbache|first=Julie|title=National Parks|url=http://www.planetecuador.net/parks.htm|accessdate=29 November 2011}}</ref>
== Climate == [[File:Culcitium.jpg|thumb|right|''[[Culcitium]]'' sp. in PÃ¡ramo de Chiles, [[Carchi]], [[Ecuador]].]] PÃ¡ramo climates differ slightly depending on the specific location. In Colombia and northern Ecuador, air masses from the [[Intertropical Convergence Zone]] (ITCZ) have a substantial effect on the climate, and these regions tend to be consistently humid (approx. 70-85%)<ref name=Luteyn>{{cite book|last=Luteyn|first=James L.|title=PÃ¡ramos: A Checklist of Plant Diversity, Geographical Distribution, and Botanical Literature|year=1999|publisher=New York Botanical Garden Press|location=Bronx, New York}}</ref> throughout the year. The Andes also play a key role in the climate of these regions as they cause an orographic uplift in which moist air rises. This creates continuous moisture via rain, clouds, and fog, with many of them receiving over {{convert|2000|mm|abbr=on}} of rain annually.<ref name="Luteyn" />
The pÃ¡ramos of the northern-most Andes of Venezuela, northern Colombia, and Costa Rica experience a different climate due to the dry season, which is caused by northeasterly trade winds. Southern Ecuador and northern Peru experience the most severe dryness as they are influenced by an air mass from the Amazon Basin, which releases its moisture on the eastern slopes, as well as another air mass from the west that is influenced by the [[Humboldt Current]].
Overall, pÃ¡ramo climates are known for their daily fluctuations in temperature and humidity. While they are generally cold and humid ecosystems, they often undergo a sudden and drastic change in weather in which they fluctuate between temperatures from below freezing to as high as {{convert|30|C|F|abbr=on}}. This oscillation often results in a daily freeze-and-thaw cycle, sometimes described as "summer every day and winter every night."<ref name="Luteyn" /> Mean annual temperatures of pÃ¡ramo ecosystems range from {{convert|2|C|F|abbr=on}} to {{convert|10|C|F|abbr=on}}, with increasingly colder temperatures at higher latitudes.
== Soils== [[File:Rabanal.JPG|thumb|left|PÃ¡ramo de Rabanal, [[BoyacÃ¡ Department|BoyacÃ¡]], Colombia]] Soils in pÃ¡ramo ecosystems vary, but most are young and partially weathered. The soil has a relatively low pH because of an abundance of moisture and organic content. Organic content, even within disturbed sites averages very high which contributes to water retention in the soil. During cold and wet weather, there are few nutrients available and productivity is very low in pÃ¡ramo soils.<ref name=Hofstede>{{cite journal|last=Hofstede|first=Robert|author2=Arnout Rossenaar |title=Biomass of Grazed, Burned, and Undisturbed PÃ¡ramo Grasslands, Colombia. II. Root Mass and Aboveground:Belowground Ratio|journal=Arctic and Alpine Research|date=February 1995|volume=27|issue=1|pages=13â18|jstor=1552063|doi=10.2307/1552063}}</ref> Soils in pÃ¡ramo ecosystems have changed because of human activity, especially due to burning vegetation to clear land for grazing.
Soils in the south Ecuadorian pÃ¡ramo are characterized broadly into [[Andisols]], [[Inceptisols]], [[Histosols]], [[Entisols]], and [[Mollisols]].<ref name="Luteyn" /> Recently, there has been an increase in Andisol soils, largely due to more volcanic activity<ref name=Buytaert>{{cite journal|last=Buytaert|first=W.|author2=J. Sevink |author3=B. De Leeuw |author4=J. Deckers |title=Clay mineralogy of the soils in the south Ecuadorian pÃ¡ramo region|journal=Geoderma|year=2005|volume=127|pages=114â129|url=http://www.paramo.be/pubs/geoderma.pdf|accessdate=2 November 2011|doi=10.1016/j.geoderma.2004.11.021}}</ref> These soils have a very high water retention rate, which contributes to the rise in cultivation and differential land use. This water supply stored in the soil in the higher elevation pÃ¡ramo in the Andes becomes the water supply for Andean settlements in lower altitudes. {{Clear}}
==Vegetation zones== PÃ¡ramos are divided into separate zones based on altitude and vegetation structure, with the three main types of pÃ¡ramo vegetation unequally distributed throughout the different zones. [[File:Azorella peduculata (14401587732).jpg|thumb|''[[Azorella pedunculata]]'']]
SuperpÃ¡ramo is at the highest elevation and is usually considered to be the transition zone between the higher, permanent snow region and the lower grass pÃ¡ramo zone. The superpÃ¡ramo zone is generally narrow and exists atop loose stones and sandy soils at about {{convert|4500|-|4800|m|abbr=on}}. It has the lowest air temperature, precipitation level, soil water-holding capacity, and nutrient content of all the zones. Being the highest in altitude, it also has the highest levels of solar radiation and night frost. For this reason, vegetation in the superpÃ¡ramo must be highly resistant to such severe fluctuations in weather. Air temperatures are low - cold at night and cool during the day with daily oscillations greater than the oscillations of monthly averages.<ref name="Luteyn" /> Due to its localization on high mountains, this area is the least disturbed by humans and contains the most endemic species of all the zones. Flora includes ''[[Azorella pedunculata]]'' of the [[Apiaceae]] family and species from the [[Asteraceae]], [[Fabaceae]], and [[Ericaceae]] families.
[[File:BlÃ¼hende Rosetten.jpg|thumb|left|''[[Espeletia]] grandiflora'' in PÃ¡ramo de Guerrero, [[Colombia]]]] [[File:Espeletia killipii 1.JPG|thumb|''Espeletia killipii'' in PÃ¡ramo de [[Guasca]], Colombia.]] The most broadly described zone is the grass pÃ¡ramo. Grass pÃ¡ramos cover large areas of mountain ranges, while others are limited to small areas on slopes and summits of very high mountains.<ref name=Sklenar>{{cite journal|last=Sklenar|first=P.|author2=P.M. Jorgensen |title=Distribution Patterns of Paramo Plants in Ecuador|journal=Journal of Biogeography|date=July 1999|volume=26|issue=4|pages=681â691|jstor=2656172|doi=10.1046/j.1365-2699.1999.00324.x}}</ref> The term "pÃ¡ramo" is sometimes used to refer to this specific type. It has continuous vegetation and plant cover with a "yellowish to oliveâbrown" look due to the combination of dead and living grasses.<ref name="Luteyn" /> The grass pÃ¡ramo extends from approximately {{convert|3500|-|4100|m|abbr=on}}, and is composed of mostly tussock-grasses and bunch-grasses.<ref name="Luteyn" /> Grasses of the ''[[Calamagrostis]]'' and ''[[Festuca]]'' genera tend to dominate this zone. Other common vegetation includes large and small shrubs, stunted trees, cushion plants, herbs, and rosette plants.<ref name="Luteyn" /> While these are the dominant species, grass pÃ¡ramos can also contain tall- and short-grass communities, including herbaceous and woody vegetation. Due to its easier access and high levels of grass, this zone is more impacted by humans and suffers from both burning and grazing activities.
SubpÃ¡ramo is the lowest and most diverse zone. At {{convert|3000|-|3500|m|abbr=on}}, it is a shrub-dominated zone that combines aspects of both the grass pÃ¡ramo above and the forest below. Along with shrubs, this zone also contains small, scattered trees which gradually transition into the grasses and herbs of the grass pÃ¡ramo above. Plant communities in this vegetation zone are also known to include thickets that are mainly composed of shrubby or woody vegetation, including species from the ''[[Ilex]]'', ''[[Ageratina]]'', and ''[[Baccharis]]'' genera. Fragmented forests can appear in the subpÃ¡ramo due to [[microclimate|microclimatic]] or [[edaphic]] conditions, yet the more abrupt changes are generally due to anthropogenic disruption such as cutting, burning, and grazing activities. Because of these high levels of disruption, it is believed that subpÃ¡ramos are made up of largely secondary-growth communities. The high levels of disruption also make this zone particularly difficult to define, as humans typically extend and expand the zone for their own purposes, sometimes over hundreds or thousands of years. This has altered forest lines, often lowering them by several hundred meters, which has also affected the [[zoning habitat]]s for many animals.
==Fauna== [[File:Pudu mephistolephis.png|thumb|''Pudu mephistolephis'', the Northern [[PudÃº]], the smallest deer in the world, found up to 4,000 metres]] [[File:Osoandino.JPG|thumb|''Tremarctos ornatus'', the [[spectacled bear]] or Andean bear is the only surviving species of bear native to South America.]]
The vegetation of the pÃ¡ramo provides shelter and habitat for a variety of mammals, birds, insects, amphibians, and reptiles. Some animals commonly found in pÃ¡ramo ecosystems include the [[Culpeo]] (sometimes called the pÃ¡ramo wolf), the [[white-tailed deer]], and the [[spectacled bear]] which occasionally forages in the high pÃ¡ramo for its favored food, ''[[Puya (genus)|Puya]]'' bromeliads.<ref name="Travel site" /> Invertebrates such as grasshoppers, cockroaches, beetles, and flies are found in the subpÃ¡ramo. Amphibians have been well documented in pÃ¡ramo ecosystems, including [[salamander]]s such as ''[[Bolitoglossa]]'' species and frogs such as ''[[Eleutherodactylus]]'' species. Reptiles include lizards of the genera ''[[Stenocercus]]'', ''[[Phenacosaurus]]'', and ''[[Proctoporus]]''.
Sixty-nine species of birds are considered to be "total users" of pÃ¡ramo habitats, with "41 species making it their primary habitat and 16 as [[indicator species]]".<ref name="Luteyn" /> The [[Andean condor]], also called "king of the Andes", is known for its wide wingspan, but is no longer frequently seen. The most numerous bird families in the pÃ¡ramo include [[eagle]]s, [[hummingbird]]s, [[Ovenbird (family)|ovenbirds]], [[Tanager|thraupid "finches"]], and [[tyrant flycatcher]]s.<ref name="Travel site">{{cite web|title=Biodiversity: Paramo Regions|url=http://www.ecuador-travel.net/biodiversity.ecosystems.paramo.htm|accessdate=29 November 2011}}</ref> Some hummingbirds tolerate the cold climate by going into "a kind of nightly hibernation."<ref name="Travel site"/>
Hummingbirds, bees and flies are all important [[pollinator]]s in the pÃ¡ramo, while birds and smaller mammals such as [[rabbit]]s and [[Cavia|guinea pigs]] are important [[seed dispersal|seed dispersers]]. Many of the larger mammals of the pÃ¡ramo are rare due to hunting.
==Human impact and climate change== [[File:Charolais cattle, Sierra Nevada, Venezuela.jpg|thumb|Cattle were introduced to the pÃ¡ramos in the early 18th century. A feral [[Charolais cattle|charolais bull]] in the [[Sierra Nevada de MÃ©rida|Sierra Nevada]], Venezuela]] [[File:Erosioenparamo.jpg|thumb|[[Erosion]] in a pÃ¡ramo, caused by wind and [[overgrazing]]]]
Humans have inhabited the pÃ¡ramo of the Andes for approximately the past 15,000 years. Deforestation has been extensive and in some cases, like the northern Andes, 90-95% of forests have been cleared. Other sites in Venezuela and Colombia show evidence that humans settled there at least 800 years ago and used the land for agriculture and hunting.<ref name="Luteyn" />
When Europeans came to the Americas they introduced exotic plants and animals that greatly affected the land, especially cattle, which were introduced to the pÃ¡ramos in the early 18th century. By the 20th century the growing population of settlers led to an increased demand for land, and pÃ¡ramo ecosystems suffered accordingly. As more land was needed for cattle, fire was used to clear land, and eventually pÃ¡ramos became excessively burned and overgrazed. Both burning and grazing have damaged vegetation, soils, species diversity, and water storage capacity of the pÃ¡ramos. In burned and disturbed sites that were studied in the Andes the pH and phosphorus concentration in the soil are higher than in non-burned sites.<ref name=Suarez>{{cite journal|last=SuÃ¡rez|first=Esteban|author2=Galo Medina |title=Vegetation Structure and Soil Properties in Ecuadorian PÃ¡ramo Grasslands with Different Histories of Burning and Grazing|journal=Arctic, Antarctic, and Alpine Research|date=May 2001|volume=33|issue=2|pages=158â164|jstor=1552216|doi=10.2307/1552216}}</ref> <!-- [[File:PÃ¡ramo andino venezolano nevado.jpg|thumb|right|Snowfall in a pÃ¡ramo in the [[Sierra La Culata|Sierra La Culata, Venezuela]]]] --> [[Climate change]] is becoming an increasingly pressing issue for pÃ¡ramo ecosystems. Growing populations in Colombia, Venezuela, and Ecuador have forced settlements in higher elevations covering more pÃ¡ramo. Recent developments such as construction of aqueducts, drainage systems, and roads, mining, and afforestation have been a huge additional pÃ¡ramo disturbance. Increases in temperature extremes are forcing many fauna and flora species to higher grounds, and eventually they could face extinction. The flora of pÃ¡ramos is adapted to specific conditions and is thus vulnerable to even small climatic change. Climate change in the Andes is causing glaciers in the pÃ¡ramo to disappear and a drop in rainfall, virtually drying up pÃ¡ramo and in turn, drying up the water supply for cities such as Quito, Ecuador and BogotÃ¡, Colombia.
On 8 February 2016, the [[Constitutional Court of Colombia]] banned all mining operations in the paramos, prioritising the protection of the environment, and terminating 347 mining licenses that had operational rights in the ecosystem.<ref>http://www.eltiempo.com/politica/justicia/corte-constitucional-prohibe-proyectos-mineros-en-los-paramos-del-pais/16504666</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}<!--added under references heading by script-assisted edit--> {{refbegin}} * {{cite book|last=Nieto Escalante |first=Juan Antonio |last2=Sepulveda Fajardo |first2=Claudia InÃ©s |last3=Sandoval SÃ¡enz |first3=Luis Fernando |last4=Siachoque Bernal |first4=Ricardo Fabian |last5=Fajardo Fajardo |first5=Jair Olando |last6=MartÃ­nez DÃ­az |first6=William Alberto |last7=Bustamante MÃ©ndez |first7=Orlando |last8=Oviedo CalderÃ³n |first8=Diana Rocio |year=2010 |title=GeografÃ­a de Colombia - Geography of Colombia |location=BogotÃ¡, Colombia |publisher=Instituto GeogrÃ¡fico AgustÃ­n Codazzi |pages=1â367 |isbn=978-958-8323-38-1 |language=es}} * {{cite book|last1=Wills |first1=Fernando |last2=etal| year=2001 |title=Nuestro patrimonio - 100 tesoros de Colombia - Our heritage - 100 treasures of Colombia |publisher=[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]] |pages=1â311 |isbn=958-8089-16-6 |language=es|displayauthors=1 }} {{refend}}

[[File:Roteiro da India Oriental00.jpg|thumb]] {{Unreferenced|date=October 2014}} A '''Roteiro''' was a Portuguese navigational route description compiled to aid sailors and pilots and used from the 16th to the 19th centuries, an early version of a [[Baedeker Guide]]. The Portuguese word 'roteiro' translates as 'route'.
Well-known roteiros are:
Aleixo da Mota's [http://purl.pt/22867/1/ roteiro of the 1600s], describing the route from India along the African coast.
The 1666 [https://archive.org/details/roteirodaindiaor00carn ''Roteiro da India Oriental''] by Antonio de Maris Carneiro, which describes the coastline from [[Sofala]] to [[Mombasa]], noting harbours and sandbars, [[Cape Finisterre]] and the [[Strait of Gibraltar]].
The 1823 [https://archive.org/details/roteirodacostado00frei ''Roteiro da costa do MaranhaÃµ eParÃ¡''] by AntÃ³nio GregÃ³rio de Freitas, covering the coastline of [[MaranhÃ£o]] and [[ParÃ¡]], two northeastern states of [[Brazil]].

{{For|the Senate Appropriations Committee - Defense|United States Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Defense}} {{Infobox spaceflight |auto=all | name = SAC-D | image = SAC-D (transparent).png | image_caption = Artist's impression of SAC-D | image_size = 275px | mission_type = Technology demonstration
Earth observation | operator = [[CONAE]] | COSPAR_ID = 2011-024A | SATCAT = 37673 | website = {{URL|http://www.conae.gov.ar/index.php/english/satellite-missions/sac-d/objectives|conae.gov.ar}} | mission_duration = Planned: 5 years
Final: {{time interval|10 June 2011 14:20:13|8 June 2015|show=ymd|sep=,}} | spacecraft_bus = Small Satellite Standard Platform{{cite web |url=https://directory.eoportal.org/web/eoportal/satellite-missions/s/sac-d |title=SAC-D (SatÃ©lite de Aplicaciones CientÃ­ficas-D)/Aquarius Mission |work=eoPortal |publisher=European Space Agency |accessdate=18 December 2015}} | manufacturer = [[INVAP]]{{cite web |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/press_kits/aquariusLaunch.pdf |title=Press Kit: Aquarius/SAC-D Launch |publisher=NASA |date=June 2011 |accessdate=18 December 2015}} | launch_mass = {{convert|2977|lb|kg|order=flip|abbr=on}} | dimensions = {{convert|8.9|xx|16.4|ft|m|order=flip|abbr=on}} | power = 1,362 watts | launch_date = {{start-date|10 June 2011, 14:20:13}} [[UTC]]{{cite news |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2011/06/live-ula-delta-ii-launch-sac-d-spacecraft/ |title=ULA Delta II launches with the SAC-D spacecraft |work=NASA Spaceflight |first=William |last=Graham |date=10 June 2011 |accessdate=18 December 2015}} | launch_rocket = [[Delta II]] 7320-10C | launch_site = [[Vandenberg Air Force Base|Vandenberg]] [[Vandenberg AFB Space Launch Complex 2|SLC-2W]] | launch_contractor = [[United Launch Alliance]] | disposal_type = Spacecraft failure | last_contact = {{end-date|8 June 2015}} | decay_date = | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Low Earth orbit|Low Earth]] | orbit_semimajor = {{convert|7031.6|km|mi|abbr=on}} | orbit_eccentricity = 0.000181 | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|652.2|km|mi|abbr=on}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|654.7|km|mi|abbr=on}} | orbit_inclination = 98.0 degrees | orbit_period = 97.8 minutes | orbit_epoch = 17 December 2015, 15:47:23 UTC{{cite web |url=http://www.heavens-above.com/orbit.aspx?satid=37673 |title=Aquarius - Orbit |work=Heavens Above |date=17 December 2015 |accessdate=18 December 2015}} | apsis = gee | instruments_list = {{Infobox spaceflight/Instruments | acronym1 =   | name1 = [[Aquarius (SAC-D instrument)|Aquarius]] | acronym2 = MWR | name2 = Microwave Radiometer | acronym3 = NIRST | name3 = New Infrared Sensor Technology | acronym4 = HSC | name4 = High Sensitivity Camera | acronym5 = DCS | name5 = Data Collection System | acronym6 = TDP | name6 = Technological Demonstration Package | acronym7 = ROSA | name7 = Radio Occultation Sounder for Atmosphere | acronym8 = ICARE-NG | name8 = Influence of Space Radiation on Advanced Components-New Generation | acronym9 = SODAD | name9 = Orbital System for an Active Detection of Debris }} }} '''SAC-D''' ({{lang-es|SatÃ©lite de Aplicaciones CientÃ­ficas-D}}, meaning ''Satellite for Scientific Applications-D''), also known as '''Aquarius''' after its primary instrument, is an [[Argentina|Argentine]] Earth science [[satellite]] built by [[INVAP]] and operated by [[ComisiÃ³n Nacional de Actividades Espaciales|CONAE]]. SAC-D was launched from Vandenberg Air Force Base on 10 June 2011, with a planned mission life of five years. Due to a power system failure, the mission was ended on 8 June 2015.{{cite news |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/2015/06/17/international-ocean-research-observatory-fails-in-orbit/ |title=International ocean research observatory fails in orbit |work=Spaceflight Now |first=Stephen |last=Clark |date=17 June 2015 |accessdate=18 June 2015}} ==Description== SAC-D was an international collaboration between the space agencies of Argentina and the United States, [[ComisiÃ³n Nacional de Actividades Espaciales|CONAE]] and [[NASA]], with participation from Brazil ([[National Institute for Space Research|INPE]]), Canada ([[Canadian Space Agency|CSA]]), France ([[CNES]]) and Italy ([[Italian Space Agency|ASI]]).{{cite news |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2015/06/farewell-aquarius-sac-d-spacecraft-mission/ |title=Farewell Aquarius as SAC-D spacecraft concludes its mission |work=NASA Spaceflight |first1=William |last1=Graham |first2=Chris |last2=Bergin |date=17 June 2015 |accessdate=18 December 2015}} It carried five Earth observation instruments (NASA, CONAE, CSA, ASI), two space science instruments (CNES), a data collection instrument (CONAE), and a technology demonstration system (CONAE).{{cite web |url=http://www.conae.gov.ar/index.php/english/satellite-missions/sac-d/instruments |title=Aquarius/SAC-D onboard instruments |publisher=CONAE |accessdate=18 December 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://aquarius.umaine.edu/docs/Aquarius_Mission_Brochure_508_Compliant.pdf |title=Aquarius/SAC-D: Sea Surface Salinity from Space |publisher=NASA/University of Maine |first1=Nicole |last1=Miklus |first2=Annette |last2=deCharon |date=2010 |accessdate=18 December 2015}} The spacecraft's main instrument, [[Aquarius (SAC-D instrument)|Aquarius]], was built by NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory and Goddard Space Flight Center. It collected data from 25 August 2011 to 7 June 2015, exceeding its intended three year primary mission.{{cite news |url=http://aquarius.umaine.edu/cgi/status_more.htm?id=116 |title=PI Announcement to Science Team and Broader Science Community |publisher=University of Maine |first1=Gary |last1=Lagerloef |first2=Sandra |last2=Torrusio |date=18 June 2015 |accessdate=18 December 2015}} Aquarius' mission was to demonstrate that accurate measurements of salinity could be made from space, and was the first spaceborne instrument to use both passive radiometers and active radar in the [[L band]]. By measuring ocean salinity, scientists are better able to understand the Earth's [[water cycle]] and ocean circulation. Project scientists later derived a method of pulling soil moisture data from Aquarius' radiometer. ==Launch== [[Image:Aquarius SAC-D Launch.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Launch of SAC-D]] NASA launched SAC-D from [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]]'s [[Vandenberg AFB Space Launch Complex 2|Space Launch Complex 2W]] aboard a [[Delta II]] 7320-10C on 10 June 2011 at 14:20:13 UTC.{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/aquarius/news/aquarius20110610.html |title=NASA's 'Age of Aquarius' Dawns With California Launch |publisher=NASA |first1=Alan |last1=Buis |first2=Steve |last2=Cole |date=10 June 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2011}} The launch was delayed from May 2010 because development of the spacecraft was taking longer than expected.{{cite news |url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/news/n0912/26aquarius/ |title=Ocean-watching satellite facing delays in Argentina |work=Spaceflight Now |first=Stephen |last=Clark |date=26 December 2009 |accessdate=6 January 2010}} ==Accomplishments== The Aquarius instrument's surface salinity measurements contributed to a better understanding of ocean dynamics and advancing climate and ocean models, both from season to season and year to year. The models still are improving El NiÃ±o prediction. Aquarius global salinity maps show how freshwater plumes coming from the mouth of large rivers and the precipitation and evaporation over the oceans affect the salinity structure of the ocean. âThe Aquarius sensor collected three years and nine months of valuable data. It was truly a pioneering effort to determine how accurately we could measure ocean salinity from space and for the first time study large and small-scale interactions of the global water cycle.â Aquarius principal investigator Gary Lagerloef of Earth & Space Research, Seattle. Aquarius provided information into the natural exchange of freshwater between the ocean, atmosphere and sea ice, which influences ocean circulation, weather and climate. Data from Aquarius showed how extreme floods affect the seas and how low-salinity river plumes affect hurricane intensity. Aquarius data was important to the Salinity Processes in the Upper Ocean Regional Study (SPURS), a year-long international field study of the oceanographic processes that sustain the maximum surface salinities in the central subtropical North Atlantic, and influence global ocean circulation. The Aquarius instrument successfully achieved its science objectives and completed its primary three-year mission in November 2014. ==Failure of spacecraft== On 7 June 2015 at 12:53:17 UTC, telemetry indicated a failure of the spacecraft's Remote Terminal Unit (RTU), causing loss of onboard power regulation and attitude stabilization. While efforts were made to recover the spacecraft, the mission was declared over on 8 June.{{cite web |url=http://www.nasa.gov/press-release/international-spacecraft-carrying-nasa-s-aquarius-instrument-ends-operations |title=International Spacecraft Carrying NASA's Aquarius Instrument Ends Operations |publisher=NASA |first1=Dwayne |last1=Brown |first2=Rani |last2=Gran |first3=Alan |last3=Buis |date=17 June 2015 |accessdate=18 December 2015}} ==Instruments== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Abbreviation !! Name !! Operator !! Purpose |- | {{n/a}} || [[Aquarius (SAC-D instrument)|Aquarius]] || [[NASA]] || Ocean [[salinity]] research |- | MWR || Microwave Radiometer || [[ComisiÃ³n Nacional de Actividades Espaciales|CONAE]] || [[Radiometry]] |- | NIRST || New Infrared Sensor Technology || CONAE
[[Canadian Space Agency|CSA]] || [[Infrared]] imagery, determination of sea temperatures |- | HSC || High Sensitivity Camera || CONAE || Imaging of [[aurora]]e, fires, and lights |- | DCS || Data Collection System || CONAE || Collection of data provided by platforms on Earth. Compatible with [[Argos system]] |- | TDP || Technological Demonstration Package || CONAE || Technology demonstration involving [[Global Positioning System|GPS]] navigation and [[inertial guidance]] |- | ROSA || Radio Occultation Sounder for Atmosphere || [[Italian Space Agency|ASI]] || Measurement of temperature and humidity in the atmosphere |- | ICARE-NG || Influence of Space Radiation on Advanced Components-New Generation || [[CNES]] || Part of CARMEN-1 mission; study of [[cosmic radiation]] and its effects on electronics |- | SODAD || Orbital System for an Active Detection of Debris || [[CNES]] || Part of CARMEN-1 mission; study of particles and debris in space |} ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[2011 in spaceflight]] * [[Jason-1]] * [[Ocean Surface Topography Mission]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|SAC-D}} * [http://www.conae.gov.ar/index.php/english/satellite-missions/sac-d/objectives SAC-D website] by CONAE * [http://www.invap.com.ar/en/aerospace-and-government/space-projects/sac-d-aquarius-satellite.html SAC-D website] by INVAP * [http://www.nasa.gov/aquarius/ Aquarius website] by NASA * [http://aquarius.umaine.edu/ Aquarius website] by the University of Maine {{Argentina space program}} {{Orbital launches in 2011}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2011]] [[Category:Satellites of Argentina]] [[Category:Earth observation satellites]]
